The property, an A-Grade business park, is fully leased to Optus Administration for 8.6 years with a fixed annual escalation of 3%. The acquisition is expected to boost the trust's distribution per unit and distribution yield by 5.7% and 5.6% respectively, and its Australian assets will make up 18% of its portfolio.

site_title: Saving the earth with degradable shopping bags
summary: Indonesian social entrepreneur Sugianto Tandio has successfully produced degradable plastic bags using proprietary technology, supplying them to major retailers in Indonesia and the US. His company, PT Tirta Marta, sells around 500 tonnes of degradable bags a month, and has licensed the technology to 20 plastic bag manufacturers in Indonesia. Tandio aims to expand to Singapore and other countries, citing a lack of similar legislation and consumer complacency about degradable bags. However, the Singapore Environment Council notes that biodegradable bags may not be the solution due to concerns about material recycling and greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: EU economy bouncing back stronger than ever: Barroso
summary: The European Union's economy is showing signs of recovery, with growth expected to rise to 1.4% in 2014, according to European Commission President José Manuel Barroso. The EU has a manufacturing trade surplus of almost 300 million euros and a services surplus of over 100 billion euros. Barroso notes that the EU's growth model, based on international reforms and openness, is more sustainable than before. The EU and China are in talks to finalize an investment treaty, aiming to boost bilateral trade to US$1 trillion by 2020.

site_title: No need for phone numbers with CallmyName app
summary: A new app called CallmyName allows users to make calls to businesses and individuals by simply typing their name on their mobile phone, eliminating the need to remember phone numbers. The app, launched in Singapore by Global Yellow Pages, is available for free and costs $500 to register a business name. This technology, developed in 2008, is now available in Singapore, the UK, Russia, and Germany, and aims to enhance brand recall for businesses while making it easier for consumers to find what they need.

site_title: Taxing times for S'pore as corporate strategy faces scrutiny
summary: Singapore is under scrutiny from other countries for its corporate strategy, with many multinational corporations (MNCs) booking significant amounts of revenue and profits in the city-state. Apple Inc. booked $14.9 billion in revenue in Singapore in 2012, more than the entire country's population could have bought. The city-state's low tax rates and generous tax incentive programs are key drivers behind its economic success, but this has raised concerns about tax avoidance. The OECD is pushing for tougher rules on transfer pricing, which could make it harder for firms to book profits in low-tax jurisdictions, and Singapore is under pressure to review its tax incentive schemes and defend its principles of value creation.

site_title: Cordlife's CEO runs a tight ship
summary: Cordlife's CEO Jeremy Yee has implemented a frugal approach to corporate spending, evident in the lack of carpeting at the company's headquarters. Despite growing revenue 14.6% to $34.7 million, Yee's tight grip on expenditure is shown in the 12.9% growth in selling and marketing expenses. Cordlife's stock price has more-than-doubled its offer price since its public listing in March last year, with no indication of Yee's approach changing.

site_title: US firms step up services exports to Singapore
summary: US firms have increased their services exports to Singapore, with the surplus growing from $3.5 billion in 2002 to $7.3 billion last year. The export of US private services to Singapore more than doubled to $12.3 billion, while the US trade balance in services with Singapore narrowed from 2.8 to 2.5 times. This trend is part of the US's renewed push for services exports in high-growth Asian markets, with Singapore seeing a 91.2% surge in US services shipments since 2009.

site_title: SGX chief regulatory and risk officer to retire
summary: SGX's chief regulatory and risk officer, Yeo Lian Sim, will retire at year-end, after nearly 9 years in the role. She will be replaced by Richard Teng as chief regulatory officer and Agnes Koh as chief risk officer. Yeo, 64, has built a well-respected risk management and regulatory function at SGX, and her legacy includes leading the exchange to meet international standards on clearing and risk management. She will remain as a special adviser to SGX after her retirement.

site_title: S-E Asia's luxury market taps mobile technology
summary: South-east Asia's luxury market is tapping into mobile technology, with 87% of Singaporeans and 80% of Malaysians owning a mobile device. This is significantly higher than the US rate of 65%. The luxury market in the region is expected to grow 11% this year, reaching $10.2 billion in sales, driven by mobile transactions now accounting for 5% of all luxury sales worldwide. Companies like Kering and LVMH are updating their Internet strategies to include mobile marketing, with tailored websites and apps to reach consumers.

site_title: CIMB scores surprise win with Australia dairy mandate
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd has secured a surprise win in Australia's dairy industry by clinching the sellside mandate to advise Warrnambool Cheese and Butter Factory Co. in a three-way global takeover battle. This deal marks a significant milestone for CIMB's investment banking ambitions in Australia, where the bank has only recently established its presence. The win highlights CIMB's growing reputation in the country's investment banking circles.

site_title: EDB woos MNCs to build up 3D printing industry
summary: The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) is seeking to attract multinational companies to develop 3D printing and additive manufacturing applications in Singapore, particularly in the aerospace and medical technology sectors. EDB's managing director Yeoh Keat Chuan believes Singapore is a prime location for commercial applications due to its existing clusters in these industries. The country has seen investments in 3D printing research, including a $15 million fund for aerospace and other sectors, and has a growing number of companies, such as Rolls-Royce and Pratt & Whitney, conducting manufacturing and development work in Singapore.

site_title: Iceland firm offers to export water in supertankers
summary: Icelandic company Aqua Omnis plans to export its abundant, naturally filtered spring water to drought-stricken areas and Europe via supertankers, offering an alternative to costly desalination and recycling methods. The project, expected to start within three years and cost $300 million, aims to address the UN's prediction that nearly half the world's population may face water scarcity by 2030. The water, which is drinkable and uncontaminated, will be transported from Iceland's aquifers to distributors without treatment, with an estimated selling price of $2 per tonne.

site_title: Yen slides as Japan sticks to economic targets
summary: The Japanese yen hit a four-month low of 101.36 to the US dollar, with dealers predicting it could drop as low as 110-115 in coming months. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) may step up monetary easing to meet its inflation target, while a weakening yen is seen as a boon to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic growth targets. The Nikkei 225 stock index reached a six-month high, driven by the yen's decline and hopes of rising corporate profits.

site_title: Ageing data centres hinder S'pore's smart city ambitions
summary: Singapore's smart city ambitions are hindered by ageing data centres, which consume excessive energy and hinder energy efficiency. Schneider Electric's vice-president Benedict Soh notes that legacy data centres are a major challenge, consuming more power due to growing data demands and outdated technologies. To address this, Singapore's Infocomm Development Authority has introduced the BCA-IDA Green Mark for Existing and New Data Centres, providing a framework for improving energy efficiency and sustainability in the sector.

site_title: Viber gets swept up by sticker revolution
summary: Viber, a Cyprus-based chat app, has introduced custom emoticons or "stickers" to compete with other messaging apps like WhatsApp, KakaoTalk, and WeChat. The stickers, designed for users in Asia, are free and priced at $1.99 per pack. Viber's CEO expects a high percentage of its 200 million users to download the stickers, which will generate revenue. The company also plans to secure telco deals to offer unlimited Viber use for a flat fee. Viber's move aims to elevate the chat experience and attract users with unique stickers, different from traditional emoticons.

site_title: CAO beefs up Los Angeles team
summary: CAO, Asia's top jet fuel buyer, has recruited Randall Chin as vice-president for supply and trading in its Los Angeles office. Chin, a former Morgan Stanley consultant, will spearhead the company's trading business on the US West Coast. CAO is expanding its footprint in the region through aviation marketing and trading activities. The company is also opening a London office between the end of this year and early 2014.

site_title: Intel predicts a software-defined future for Asia
summary: Intel predicts a software-defined future for Asia, focusing on software-defined data centers (SDDCs) and Big Data analytics. The company aims to play a significant role in driving SDDC adoption and utilizing Big Data analytics effectively for business operations. Intel's vision involves developing "software hooks" or APIs to enable quick deployment and optimization of applications. The company has set up a test-bed site in the US to develop products and services related to SDDC adoption, and is also working with partners to offer Big Data analytics infrastructure and solutions.

site_title: Post-results acquisitions bulk of week's trades
summary: Singapore Exchange activity was flat last week, with 30 director transactions worth $9.8 million, mostly acquisitions following earnings announcements. Buyers outnumbered sellers, with 15 companies recording 24 purchases worth $5.4 million. Buyback activity increased, with seven companies posting 27 repurchases worth $4.7 million, but the pace remains below November averages of 26 firms and $68 million.

site_title: Getting to know tech stocks
summary: Singapore's technology sector contributes significantly to the country's economy, with over 100 firms listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) generating revenue from technology. The sector can be divided into five categories: hardware, software, semiconductors, technology services, and technology design, manufacturing, and distribution. Hardware companies, such as TPV Technology and Elec & Eltek, have seen varying price performances, with some gaining up to 221.4% and others declining by 50%. Software companies, like Silverlake Axis, have also performed well, with some gaining 73% and others declining by 45.8%. Semiconductors, essential components in electronic devices, have seen a mix of price performances, with some declining by 29.4% and others gaining 41%. Technology services companies, providing commercial applications of technological products, have seen average year-to-date gains of 12.2%.

site_title: KepLand realises $149m net gain from stake sale
summary: KEPPEL Land has sold its 51% stake in Jakarta Garden City township to PT Modernland for approximately $249 million, generating a net gain of about $149 million. The divestment will allow the company to redeploy capital to new projects in Indonesia, particularly in Jakarta. The township, expected to be fully developed with 4,000 homes, has already seen 83% of homes sold and 1,100 units completed.

site_title: Japan, US firms team up to make MRAM chips
summary: US chip giant Micron Technology and Tokyo Electron of Japan are leading a joint project to mass-produce MRAM (magnetoresistive random access memory) chips, aiming to perfect the technology within three years and start mass production by 2018. The new technology boasts a memory capacity 10 times that of DRAM, reducing electricity draw to about two-thirds. Benefits include faster computing times and lower power consumption, leading to longer-lasting batteries. Multiple Japanese and US chip makers are participating in the project, including Shin-Etsu Chemical, Renesas Electronics, and Hitachi.

site_title: Will STI close 2013 with a bang or a whimper?
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) is expected to close 2013 with a poor showing, barring a major year-end miracle. Despite initial optimism, the index rose only 5 points in 11 months, from 3,167 to 3,172. Some analysts, such as Nomura Equity Research, predicted a single-digit return for 2013, while others, like DBS Vickers, forecast a low of 3,050 and a high of 3,260. A year-end STI of 3,251 is also possible, according to OSK DMG. The index's performance was hindered by global economic concerns, including the US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing tapering and emerging market volatility.

site_title: Health food to go
summary: Singapore's health food eateries are expanding beyond their niches to appear in shopping malls and along Orchard Road, rebranding themselves as trendy fast-food outlets. Entrepreneurs are catering to a wider audience by offering gluten-free, organic, and vegan options. The trend is driven by the growing demand for allergen-free dining and convenience food, as people seek healthier alternatives to traditional fast food. Businesses like Frootkeyk, Jonathan's, and SuperNature are adapting to changing consumer preferences, with some even opening new concepts to tap into the market.

site_title: Going au naturel
summary: Korean beauty brand Innisfree launched its eco-friendly range in Singapore, featuring 10 organic Jeju ingredients. The brand, known for its natural skincare, offers oil-free products such as the Green Tea Line, Jeju Volcanic Line, and Eco-science Line. In contrast, Japanese brand Orbis introduced its 100% oil-free skincare concept in Singapore, offering products like the Aquaforce range and Petit Shake. Both brands aim to promote environmentally conscious and natural beauty practices.

site_title: Boeing warns of engine icing risk on 747-8s, Dreamliners
summary: Boeing has warned airlines about a risk of engine icing problems on its 747-8 and 787 Dreamliner planes powered by General Electric engines. The issue was caused by a build-up of ice crystals, leading to temporary loss of thrust during high-altitude flights. The problem has resulted in six incidents since April, with all aircraft landing safely. Boeing has issued a notice prohibiting the affected aircraft from flying near thunderstorms with ice crystals. GE and Boeing are working on software modifications to address the issue, which is expected to be resolved soon.

site_title: 28% of M&A deals in emerging markets hit snags
summary: A study by Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer found that nearly a third (28%) of merger-and-acquisition (M&A) deals in emerging markets hit significant setbacks, including regulatory investigations, government opposition, stakeholder litigation, and management objections. The study analyzed 132 cross-border deals in emerging markets valued over $750 million between 2008 and 2013, with India and Indonesia proving particularly challenging. Regulatory probes were the most common issue, affecting half of the troubled deals, while litigation impacted 35%. The study advises investors to consider six recurring themes before making a move in emerging markets.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) is focusing on emerging markets, including 3D printing and additive manufacturing. Meanwhile, 28% of mergers and acquisitions in emerging markets face challenges. US firms are increasing services exports to Singapore, while Cordlife's CEO emphasizes returning surplus capital to shareholders. Indonesia may see more interest rate hikes, and China's markets are expected to be volatile due to reform plans. Iran will receive $7 billion in sanctions relief, and JPMorgan Chase plans to keep compensation flat due to legal settlements.

site_title: Collectible masterpieces
summary: Jaeger-LeCoultre's new CEO, Daniel Riedo, aims to increase the brand's production capacity to meet growing demand for its intricate watches. The company faces a global shortage of skilled watchmakers, particularly for high-complication pieces, and plans to hire 250 new staff to address the issue. To speed up the training process, a new special workshop will be opened next year, allowing new hires to focus solely on honing their skills rather than meeting production numbers.

site_title: Asia firms lag in spending on digital marketing
summary: Asian companies are lagging behind Western counterparts in spending on digital marketing, according to a survey by the CMO Council. The survey found that Asian firms struggle with limited budgets and lack the skills needed to execute full digital campaigns. However, Singapore, Australia, and India are leading users of analytics in the region. By 2015, digital advertising is expected to make up 29.4% of the total marketing budget in Asia, despite the growing online audience in the region. The gap in digital marketing performance between Asia and North America is closing, but Asian marketers still need to improve their skills and investment in digital technologies.

site_title: Modern Asian perch
summary: Ku De Ta, a Pan-Asian restaurant in Singapore, has introduced a new executive chef, Frederic Faucheux, who is bringing a contemporary twist to the menu. The restaurant, located in the Marina Bay Sands, offers a range of dishes, including a chopped yellowfin tuna tartare, yutaka roll, and Australian lamb rack. While some dishes, such as the yutaka roll and lobster claw tempura, were found to be over-ambitious, others, like the Australian lamb rack and halibut, were praised for their flavors and presentation. The restaurant offers tasting menus and has a rating of 6.5 out of 10.

site_title: James Sinclair to head gold exchange
summary: James Sinclair, a precious metals specialist, has joined Singapore Precious Metals Exchange (SGPMX) as its executive chairman to expand and raise trade volumes in physical gold and silver. Sinclair aims to establish a platform for transparent valuation and capitalize on the growing demand for physical gold, particularly in Asia. He believes the market could take off within a year, driven by the gap between declining paper gold prices and rising physical gold demand, which could lead to a collapse in the paper market with unpredictable consequences.

site_title: Guthrie to be delisted on Monday
summary: Guthrie GTS, a Singapore-listed company, will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange on Monday after being taken private by Indonesian businessmen Anthoni Salim and Putra Masagung. The compulsory acquisition was completed on November 22, with the offer valued at $948.6 million. Guthrie, Singapore's oldest company, has changed hands multiple times since its establishment in 1821. The delisting marks the end of the company's 49-year stint on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: From niche to mainstream
summary: Three Singaporean businesses have expanded or rebranded to cater to specific dietary needs. SuperNature, a health food store, reopened in a larger space with more imported organic brands and a takeaway cafe. Jonathan's, a fully gluten-free bakery, offers homemade breads and desserts made with sugar-free and dairy-free ingredients. Gusto, an Italian restaurant, introduced a new gluten-free menu with 55% of its dishes gluten-free, and Greenzilla, a vegan burger joint, offers a wide selection of vegan and non-vegan options. These businesses aim to provide options for individuals with dietary restrictions and promote inclusivity.

site_title: AWS warms up to hybrid clouds
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) acknowledges the growing demand for "hybrid clouds" as companies balance private data centers and public clouds. In an interview, AWS' CTO Werner Vogels stated that while companies may want to shift more reliance to cloud providers, they won't entirely abandon their own data centers due to security and compliance concerns. AWS has been working on hybrid solutions, such as bridging its cloud with third-party clouds and improving connectivity in emerging markets like Asia. The company continues to innovate, releasing 235 services in 2013 and partnering with major vendors like SAP and Oracle.

site_title: Customers using 4 different channels to contact one organisation: survey
summary: A survey of 2,400 consumers in seven countries, including Singapore, found that customers contact a single organisation through multiple channels, with an average of four interactions required to resolve a query. Video chats are gaining traction, with 15% of respondents using the service, and 85% satisfied with the experience. Social media usage is also on the rise, particularly in South-east Asia, with 2013 seeing a significant increase in social media adoption. Consumers expect seamless and integrated experiences across channels, with 70% willing to spend more with companies providing excellent customer service.

site_title: Odd job worker jailed 4 1/2 years for being a mule
summary: Ngiam Kok Min, a 45-year-old Singaporean odd job worker, was sentenced to 54 months' imprisonment for dishonestly receiving stolen property and transferring the benefits of criminal conduct. He was promised a 3% commission for opening bank accounts for overseas remitters and received $1,249,829.23. Ngiam withdrew and passed $850,000 to Chua Gek Choo, who also faces charges. The banks were deceived into remitting money into Ngiam's accounts through fraudulent email instructions. Ngiam received $10,451.94 for his work.

site_title: Wall St's all-time high fails to rouse local bourse
summary: The Singapore stock market failed to respond positively to Wall Street's all-time high of 16,000, with the Straits Times Index closing virtually unchanged at 3,172.85. The index lost 29 points or 0.9% for the week due to a lack of liquidity, with only 1.2 billion units traded. Despite some bright spots, such as Keppel Corp's strong performance, analysts attribute the market's paralysis to concerns over the US Federal Reserve's potential asset tapering, which may start in March next year.

site_title: Straits Trading aims to set up Blackstone-style property funds
summary: Straits Trading Co, an investor in Singapore's biggest publicly traded property trust manager, plans to set up "Blackstone-like" property funds as Asia's appetite for real estate investments increases. The funds, with an eight-to-10-year time-frame, will seek to follow the model of Blackstone Group LP, the world's biggest manager of alternative assets including real estate. This move comes as cross-border property transactions in the Asia-Pacific region rose 5.5% in the third quarter, and Reits have raised US$2.7 billion through initial public offerings in Singapore, driven by an ageing population boosting demand for steady income.

site_title: Aussino halves after it gets SGX delisting notice
summary: Aussino Group shares plummeted 50% to 3.6 cents after the Singapore Exchange (SGX) rejected its application to extend its listing requirements and issued a delisting notification due to negative cash flow and a market capitalization below $40 million. The company will be delisted by December 20. Minority shareholders are scrambling for the exit, with some traders saying they are "obviously scrambling for the exit" given the company's loss-making status.

site_title: Turn on the tap - show what's brewing in Myanmar
summary: Frasers and Neaves (F&N) appears to downplay the dispute with its Myanmar partner, Myanma Economic Holding Ltd (MEHL), over a potential sale of the Myanmar Brewery business. Despite reporting record-breaking sales and maintaining market leadership, F&N fails to disclose the dispute in its full-year results announcement. The business contributes significantly to F&N's beverage business, with estimated profits of $35 million. F&N's silence raises concerns among investors, particularly with Thai Beverage Public Co controlling shareholder Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi's significant stake in the company.

site_title: High art of retail
summary: Singapore's Robinsons Orchard, a historic department store, redefines its concept with a $40 million flagship. The new store features 380 brands, including luxury labels like Manolo Blahnik and The Kooples, and aims to breathe glamour into the department store concept. Despite previous facelifts, the store's decline was seen as inevitable with the rise of online sales and trendy fashion chains. However, the new flagship is poised to attract shoppers with its upscale offerings and revitalize the department store concept.

site_title: Clash in Cotai draws boxing fans despite record ticket prices
summary: The highly anticipated boxing event "Clash in Cotai" drew a crowd of 15,000 fans in Macau, despite record-breaking ticket prices of up to $3,000. The main event features Manny Pacquiao vs Brandon Rios for the World Boxing Organization's welterweight title, with 15,000 attendees expected to watch. The event is seen as a success for Sands China, which plans to bring more high-level boxing matches to Macau next year, aiming to attract a broader range of customers and change the perception of Macau as a solely gaming destination.

site_title: Electricity market revolution on the way
summary: Singapore is on the cusp of an electricity market revolution, with the Sustainable Energy Association of Singapore predicting cheaper power for home-users once regulations allow intermittent energy sources to supply more power to the grid. The government has announced measures to promote renewable energy, such as nearly doubling the cap for power generation from intermittent sources to 600 MW. This is expected to support efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and unlock up to $4 billion worth of private sector investment in renewable energy.

site_title: NODX forecast readjusted downwards
summary: Singapore's International Enterprise (IE) has revised its forecast for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) and total trade growth to between -5% and -4%, and 1-2%, respectively, due to weaker-than-expected performance in the first nine months of the year. The revised forecasts are lower than the original 2-4% and 3-5% targets. Despite this, IE Singapore still expects NODX and total trade to grow 1-3% next year, in line with stronger global economic growth.

site_title: HK firm exits Biosensors for US$312.3m
summary: Shandong Weigao, a Chinese firm, is selling its 21.7% stake in Singapore-based medical devices firm Biosensors International Group for $312.3 million due to increased competition in China. The sale, valued at 11.7% premium, is expected to be completed by February 28, 2024. The company plans to use the proceeds as working capital and to develop its core businesses. The move is seen as a strategic exit for Shandong Weigao, which estimates a loss of $92.2 million from the sale.

site_title: Celebrating 80 years of flying in style
summary: British Airways celebrated its 80th year of flying to Singapore with a fashion show featuring iconic uniforms designed by renowned designers. The inaugural flight from London to Singapore in 1933 took 10 days, with a one-way fare costing £180. Singapore has been a key part of British Airways' network, offering daily flights to London and twice-daily flights to Sydney.

site_title: Running for good
summary: Approximately 8,000 runners participated in the SGX Bull Charge 2013 charity event in Marina Bay, raising over $3 million for charities supporting the elderly, special needs children, and adults with autism. Stuart Haynes set the 5km record with a time of 16:55 seconds, while Vivian Tang was the top female runner with a 19:17 second time.

site_title: Changi Airport consortium scores US$8.3b Rio deal
summary: A Singaporean-led consortium, including Changi Airport Group, won a US$8.3 billion concession to expand and run Rio de Janeiro's Galeão airport for 25 years. The deal, part of Brazil's push to privatize infrastructure, includes 26 new gates and expanded cargo storage. The consortium, which also includes Brazilian conglomerate Odebrecht, will invest about 5.7 billion reais over the next 25 years. This follows similar deals for airports in Sao Paulo and Brasilia, aiming to overhaul Brazil's underwhelming international gateways.

site_title: More Singaporeans succumbing to money mule temptation
summary: A significant spike in money mule cases in Singapore has been reported, with 133 cases involving $15.5 million in the first 9 months of 2013, a 43% increase from 93 cases in 2012. Individuals are being lured into becoming money mules through social networking sites, with some being duped or enticed by commissions. The police are warning that those who facilitate money laundering can face fines of up to $500,000 and/or 7 years in jail.

site_title: Culinary coup in Bangkok
summary: Ku De Ta, a luxury entertainment complex, has opened in Bangkok with a sprawling 10-in-one complex featuring three restaurants, seven bars, and a spacious dance floor. The 30,000 sq ft complex offers stunning 360-degree views of the city and caters to Bangkok's high-end crowd. The venue's managing director, Spencer Roberts, aims to provide a unique experience with seven different options, allowing patrons to visit multiple times a week. Ku De Ta's success in Singapore has paved the way for future expansions in cities worldwide, including a planned 15,000 sq ft outpost in Hong Kong and potential locations in Europe, the US, and the Middle East.

site_title: Bespoke beauty
summary: A Paris-based skincare brand, Ioma, is set to revolutionize the beauty industry with its "smart" skincare approach. The brand uses diagnostic devices based on microelectromechanical systems (Mems) to detect physical phenomena, providing scientific diagnoses for recommended products. Ioma plans to expand in Asia, particularly in Singapore, and aims to eliminate the uncertainty of buying skincare products based on advertising or word-of-mouth. The brand's founder, Jean Michel Karam, believes this technology is a game-changer in the industry, offering a more personalized approach to skincare.

images.alt_text: 'SMART' SKINCARE Ioma promises to give women and men scientific diagnoses as the basis for its recommended products

site_title: What's app and where it's at
summary: Several travel companies have introduced new mobile apps and services to enhance the travel experience. Prime Feel and Touch offers maps and points of interest for tours, while the Dream Holiday Builder allows users to customize their holidays. The Singapore Attractions Express Virtual Tour Guide system provides information on major attractions, and Insight Vacations offers free WiFi connectivity on its buses. W Hotels features an integrated music platform, and Dynasty Travel and Zuji have revamped their apps with features like travel deals, live chat, and information on destinations.

site_title: Have tech, will travel
summary: Travel companies are leveraging technology to enhance customer experience and stay competitive. Luxury land tour operator Insight Vacations offers free WiFi connectivity on its coaches, while Prime Touch and Feel launches a mobile app with virtual tour guides and a holiday builder. Online travel agencies like Zuji and TripAdvisor also introduce new features, including live chat support and mobile apps. Meanwhile, travel agents emphasize the benefits of package tours, citing their expertise, knowledge, and 24/7 emergency assistance.

site_title: Showcasing S'pore fashion design globally
summary: Singapore's Textile & Fashion Federation is promoting local fashion design globally by sending designers to industry trade shows. The federation underwrites travel and show fees for designers with a grant from International Enterprise Singapore. Since 2010, the federation has sent designers to Paris and Italy, with recent trips to South Korea and a upcoming trip to New York's Coterie trade show. The federation aims to increase awareness and sales for Singaporean designers, with a focus on emerging talent. Government support for fashion expansion is growing, with the federation receiving positive feedback from buyers and designers.

site_title: ExxonMobil cuts cracker costs with its new S'pore technology
summary: ExxonMobil has successfully built the world's first plant to convert crude oil directly into chemicals, the Singapore Parallel Train (SPT) project. The US oil giant's new 1 million tonne per annum cracker in Singapore can process an unprecedented range of feedstocks, making it more cost-competitive than rival Asian petrochemical complexes. The project doubles chemicals output at ExxonMobil's Singapore hub and provides a cost advantage over naphtha feedstock, reducing energy consumption and emissions. The technology is seen as a key to maintaining ExxonMobil's competitive edge in the face of changing feedstock landscapes and shale gas developments.

site_title: China's flash PMI for November eases as export orders drop
summary: China's manufacturing activity slowed in November due to lower-than-expected export orders, with the HSBC/Markit flash PMI easing to 50.4. Employment also decreased, and new orders rose but at a slower rate, indicating a fragile global recovery. The data was negative for markets, with shares falling in Hong Kong and Shanghai. The government's "mini stimulus" and efforts to slow credit growth may lead to a further decline in growth in the months ahead, according to economists.

site_title: Dealing with white-coat hypertension
summary: A European Society of Cardiology and European Society of Hypertension (ESH/ESC) 2013 guideline suggests distinguishing white-coat hypertension from real hypertension, as 15-30% of patients with elevated clinic blood pressure readings have white-coat hypertension. White-coat hypertension is characterized by elevated clinic blood pressure readings but normal 24-hour blood pressure readings. Patients with white-coat hypertension do not require medication, but those with underlying medical conditions or high-risk factors for heart disease may benefit from treatment. The guideline advises considering lifestyle changes, such as salt reduction and stress reduction, for patients with persistent white-coat hypertension.

site_title: The search for emotional satisfaction
summary: Korean choreographer Kim Jae Duk's first full-length production, Mr Sign, premieres at Contact 2013 dance festival, exploring themes of communication and emotional satisfaction in relationships. The piece features dancers using gibberish and text-based dance, accompanied by a score from Tchaikovsky's Swan Lake, combined with Korean trot music and Indonesian gamelan music. The festival, running from Nov 29 to Dec 8, also features international and regional artists, including Danish artist Kitt Johnson and Compania Nacional de Danza principal dancer Tamako Akiyama.

site_title: US stocks seen to outperform in 2014: Pictet
summary: US stocks are expected to outperform in 2014, according to Swiss private bank Pictet & Cie. The bank's chief investment officer, Bhaskar Laxminarayan, attributes this to the US economy's improvement and the US dollar's structural strength. Pictet advises clients to shift away from commodities, bonds, and towards US stocks and alternatives like private equity and real estate. The bank is also bearish on Asian markets, particularly North Asia, due to ongoing weakness.

site_title: LionGold's Ghana unit signs deal to buy tailings from B&C Gold
summary: LionGold's Ghana unit, Owere Mines, has signed a deal to purchase and process gold-bearing waste tailings from B&C Gold, with a minimum of 1 million tonnes expected to be processed over three years. The agreement is part of the Ghanaian government's efforts to clean up hazardous material left behind from old gold mining operations. LionGold estimates 90,000 ounces of gold can be produced from the tailings, with income from the project expected to sustain exploration activities at the Konongo Gold Project.

site_title: Apple's space ship-shaped research campus cleared
summary: Apple's space ship-shaped research campus in Cupertino, California, has received final clearance for construction after a tax break was trimmed by 15%. The 176-acre site will feature a 21st-century campus with sustainable facilities, a four-storey main building accommodating 12,000 employees, and amenities like a restaurant and fitness center. Designed by Norman Foster, the campus aims to promote innovation, collaboration, and shared creativity. Apple will continue to use its current One Infinite Loop campus, which will be redeveloped into a unified, secure, and private space.

site_title: MTI study finds positive return to training for the low-wage
summary: A Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) study of 6,000 Singaporean low-wage workers found that those who attended training between 2007 and 2009 experienced an average wage increase of 3.1%. This "positive causal return" to training occurred on top of year-to-year increments, reinforcing the importance of skills upgrading for low-wage workers. Even among those with little formal education, the returns to training remained positive, albeit lower. Policymakers are advised to focus on reaching out to non-unionized low-wage workers to encourage training participation.

site_title: Fund managers seek bargains but wary of traps in 2014
summary: Fund managers are seeking bargains in 2014, but are cautious of value traps due to a highly sensitive market outlook. The US and Japanese economies are showing signs of recovery, while Europe's deflation threatens some peripheral economies. Asset managers are focusing on income-generating stocks, particularly in cyclicals, and valuations in North Asia. Key areas of interest include healthcare, industrials, and European equities, where valuations are extremely cheap. However, the challenge is identifying winners and losers, and investors must carefully assess the catalysts that will unlock mispriced value.

site_title: The typical white- collar fraudster is closer than you think
summary: A KPMG study of 596 white-collar fraudsters in 78 countries, including Singapore, found that the typical fraudster is a highly respected, friendly, and extroverted individual, usually between 36 and 45 years old, employed in executive, finance, operations, or sales and marketing functions. The most prevalent type of fraud is misappropriation of assets, with 56% of cases involving embezzlement or procurement fraud. Companies are vulnerable to procurement fraud due to a focus on price over other factors. Technology is increasingly used by fraudsters, and companies must adapt with newer approaches such as data analytics to defend themselves.

site_title: KLW gets $6.4m contracts for three housing projects
summary: KLW Holdings has secured three contracts worth $6.4 million for residential project developments in Singapore. The contracts are for Hillsta, Waterbay EC, and The Topiary Executive Condominium, with projects expected to be completed by October 2015 and December 2015. The contracts will not have a material impact on the company's financial year ending March 31, 2014.

site_title: Developers chasing prime London land face squeeze
summary: Developers in prime London face a squeeze due to rising land prices and building costs as the luxury market cools. Land prices rose 14% in the best London areas, but with a stronger pound making UK assets more expensive, signs of a slowdown are emerging. Prime home values rose 6.8% in the year through October, the least in four years. Analysts predict a 5-6% increase in building costs this year, and interest rates may rise, potentially leading to losses on land purchases.

site_title: Over 30 countries to vie for Asian art prize
summary: The Prudential Eye Awards, a not-for-profit art prize, will be launched in January 2014 to recognize emerging Asian talent in five categories. Sponsored by Prudential and the Saatchi Gallery, the award aims to promote Asian art infrastructure and provide a platform for artists in over 30 countries, including China, Indonesia, and Australia. The overall winner will receive US$50,000 in prize money and have their works displayed in the Saatchi Gallery in London.

site_title: Correction
summary: The Singapore Press Herald (SPH Media) corrected an article stating that foreign wholesale trade increased 2.2% in the third quarter, instead of decreasing 2.2% from a year earlier. The error was in the seasonal adjustment, not the actual data.

site_title: Paterson Hill is world's 5th most expensive street
summary: Paterson Hill in Singapore has been ranked the world's fifth most expensive street, with an average price of $42,500 per square meter. Hong Kong's Pollock's Path tops the list, with an average price of $120,000 per square meter. Despite economic uncertainty, super-prime property sales continue to rise, driven by limited new supply and high demand for best properties in prime locations.

site_title: Unlock Indoor Stadium's branding value
summary: OCBC Bank secured a 15-year naming rights deal worth over $50 million for the Singapore Sports Hub's indoor facilities, including the aquatic centre, club lounges, and VIP lounge. The deal excluded the National Stadium, which will remain a historic venue, and the Singapore Indoor Stadium, which may be named after a personality in the future. The decision aims to preserve public character while attracting corporate sponsorship, but critics argue that the Singapore Indoor Stadium missed an opportunity for significant revenue.

site_title: House of Milan
summary: Clyde and Sharon Lee, a couple from Singapore, spent a week in Milan shopping for furniture for their Cairnhill apartment. They visited top brands like B&B Italia, Minotti, and Poltrona Frau, and were impressed by the passion of the Italian sales staff. The couple shipped back a container-load of designer pieces, including an L-shaped sofa and Murano glass lamps, and worked with designer Denise Gan to create a clean, modern, and timeless look. The apartment features a Travetine wall, textured panelling, and a playroom that doubles as a study for their two young sons. The couple believes the investment was worth it, as the location of the apartment is ideal for their family's needs.

site_title: Kennedy assassination: Just the facts this time
summary: The documentary "Parkland" recreates the moments leading up to and following the assassination of President John F. Kennedy 50 years ago. Written and directed by Peter Landesman, the film focuses on key people and places involved in the events, without embellishing the facts or presenting conspiracy theories. The movie explores the impact of the assassination on those directly affected, including the First Lady, FBI and Secret Service agents, and medical staff at Parkland Hospital. With a cast of ensemble actors, "Parkland" presents a matter-of-fact portrayal of a pivotal moment in American history.

site_title: Star choreographers headline triple bill
summary: UK choreographer James Cousins, winner of the Matthew Bourne Choreographer Award, will present an excerpt of his piece "Everything and Nothing" at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts' 75th anniversary celebration. Cousins will be joined by local choreographers Jeffrey Tan and Osman Abdul Hamid, who will also present new works, "Swirling" and "Currents Of Time", respectively. The triple bill will showcase a diverse range of contemporary dance styles and will be performed by 37 student dancers and five alumni dancers.

site_title: 10 Affordable Art Fair highlights
summary: The Affordable Art Fair is a platform selling accessible art below $10,000. The fair features striking pieces from various galleries, including James Nizam at Gallery Jones. Other notable galleries include Thevar 2.0, The Social Kitchen, and CMC Markets. The fair aims to make art more accessible to a wider audience, showcasing affordable and unique art pieces.

site_title: Armed pirates looting cargoes threaten African oil
summary: Armed pirates are increasingly targeting oil tankers off the coast of West Africa, with 40 piracy attacks reported in the Gulf of Guinea in the first nine months of the year. The attacks, which have become more frequent and violent, threaten shipping in the region, which produces over a third of Africa's oil. The pirates are not only stealing cargo but also taking hostages for ransom, with cases of kidnappings on the rise. International oil companies are taking extra precautions to protect their ships, and governments are calling for a stronger response to the growing threat.

site_title: The little engine that couldn't
summary: Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical "Starlight Express" lacks heart and feels like it's trying too hard, despite its dazzling costumes and roller-skating locomotives. The underdog story of Rusty, a steam engine, is hindered by harsh sound effects and flashing lights, which overpower the sincerity of the protagonist. The show's attempt at incorporating 3D technology is seen as insulting to diehard fans who have paid high prices for tickets. The production runs until Sunday at Marina Bay Sands' MasterCard Theatres.

site_title: Well-crafted thriller for the thinking man
summary: English screenwriter Steven Knight's thriller "Closed Circuit" explores the aftermath of a London bombing through a tense legal drama. The film follows lawyers Martin Rose and Claudia Simmons-Howe as they defend the bombing's primary suspect, while Rose uncovers a conspiracy theory that puts national security at risk. With a 90-minute package of edge-of-the-seat action and a dark exploration of national security, the film raises questions about the price of security and the true culprits behind the attack.

site_title: Sculptures that speak to the viewer
summary: Italian sculptor Oliviero Rainaldi's 2011 statue of Pope John Paul II, Conversazioni, was criticized for its resemblance to the late pope. Rainaldi redesigned the piece over nine months, citing personal dissatisfaction rather than criticism. The revised statue now stands in front of Rome's Termini train station. Rainaldi's works on display, including his series "Caduti" (Fallen), explore spiritual themes and raise questions about art, religion, and life. The exhibition, featuring 49 pieces, runs at the Partners & Mucciaccia Gallery until February 16.

site_title: More buyers, more galleries
summary: Singaporean art buyers are the most enthusiastic in the world, with 1 in 2.5 visitors to the Affordable Art Fair (AAF) purchasing a piece of art. The fair, which has grown from 50 galleries to 95, expects $4.5 million in sales this year. AAF Singapore is expanding to hold two fairs annually, a move seen as viable after comparing data with other cities. The fair's director notes that Singapore's art scene is multicultural, with buyers from diverse backgrounds. High-end galleries, including Gillman Barracks, have joined the fair, with some bringing in lower-priced artworks to test the market.

site_title: Malaysia acts to cool property demand
summary: Malaysia is taking steps to cool its property market amid concerns over affordability, following Singapore's four-year property boom. The country has doubled the minimum amount foreigners must spend on property and raised the capital gains tax to 30% on homes sold within five years. Local governments in Johor and Penang are considering additional tariffs on overseas buyers. The move aims to prevent a housing debacle and combat concerns over affordability, with household indebtedness rising by an average 12% per annum in the past five years.

site_title: AirAsia's Q3 profit sinks 77.5%
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia Bhd reported a 77.5% decline in third-quarter profit to RM35.8 million, due to forex losses on borrowings and low ticket fares. The airline's average fare in Malaysia fell 12% and passenger volumes increased 11%. This lower profit compared to Malaysian Airline System (MAS), which reported a net loss of RM375.4 million, likely due to higher operating expenses.

site_title: Their chemistry comes from fast friendship
summary: Matt Laurent and Alessandra Ferrari, stars of the musical Notre Dame de Paris, have developed a strong chemistry on and off stage. The pair, who have worked together for four years, credit their fast friendship as crucial to their acting. Ferrari attributes playing Esmeralda to bringing out her emotional side, while Laurent channels his inner Quasimodo through personal experiences. The musical, which premiered in 1998, has enjoyed a successful tour, with over 4,000 performances in 20 countries, and will open in Singapore next month.

site_title: A thoughtful entertainment that stays true to its origins
summary: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire, the second installment of the trilogy, stays true to its origins and proves that young adult movies can also appeal to a broader demographic. Jennifer Lawrence reprises her role as Katniss Everdeen, navigating the complexities of her character as she faces a new challenge in the gladiatorial games. The film distinguishes itself from its teen-themed counterparts by maintaining its thought-provoking and well-executed content, featuring a well-cast ensemble and top-notch veterans in secondary roles. The movie sets the stage for the final installment, with Katniss becoming a symbol of hope for the rebellion.

site_title: Tigerair's website glitches irk public, may impact sales
summary: Tigerair's website experienced technical issues for at least two days, causing booking problems and impacting sales. The airline's payment gateway was down due to a scheduled maintenance event, but the issue was resolved. Customers reported difficulties booking flights online, with some experiencing double bookings. The website is a key platform for ticket sales, accounting for around 80% of bookings, according to analysts. Tigerair apologized for the inconvenience and advised customers to contact customer care if they didn't receive an emailed confirmation within 24 hours.

site_title: CosmoSteel's Q4 profit plunges 53.3% to $1.16m
summary: CosmoSteel Holdings reported a net profit of $1.16 million for the fourth quarter, down 53.3% year-over-year, due to a competitive business environment. Revenue rose 24.4% to $33.63 million, driven by stronger sales in the energy and marine sectors. The company aims to identify new markets and opportunities for growth while maintaining cost management to protect margins.

site_title: Foreign investors eyeing Indonesia's airport needs
summary: Foreign investors are eyeing Indonesia's airport needs due to the country's growing air travel market and need for investment. Next month, Indonesia is expected to relax regulations allowing foreign companies to manage and operate airports. This change is expected to attract companies like India's GVK Power & Infrastructure and South Korea's Incheon International Airport Corp. Indonesia's airports are operating at capacity, and the country risks losing market share to regional hubs if it doesn't expand. Foreign firms are eager to invest in Indonesia's airports, but current regulations limit foreign involvement to 49% ownership.

site_title: More to the French than the kiss
summary: SingTheatre's production "A French Kiss in Singapore" is a musical revue featuring dance, music, and sketches based on the music of French artists Charles Aznavour, Serge Gainsbourg, Jacques Brel, and Charles Trenet. The show explores various types of love, not just romantic love, and will run from November 27 to December 7 at the School of the Arts Drama Theatre. The all-male cast, including local actor Hossan Leong, will perform 23 songs, with only two and a half in French, and will aim to showcase French culture beyond its stereotypes.

site_title: Around Town
summary: Theatre performances include British director Peter Brook's staging of "The Suit" at the DBS Arts Centre until November 25, and "Citizen Pig" by The Finger Players at the Drama Centre Black Box from November 28 to December 1. Australian singer-songwriter Lenka performs at the Esplanade Theatre on November 26. The Etiquette III - Truth or Dare exhibition features visual arts and film components at The Substation Gallery until November 29.

site_title: CapLand pares Australand stake for A$426m
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property giant, sold a third of its stake in Australian developer Australand for A$426 million (S$485 million), reducing its stake from 59.1% to 39.1%. The sale will improve Australand's liquidity and attract institutional investors, with proceeds to be used for investments in Singapore and China, and general working capital. Despite a reported loss of S$127.5 million due to foreign currency translation and hedging, analysts remain positive on CapitaLand.

site_title: HK's Gaw, partners buy London building
summary: Hong Kong-based private equity firm Gaw Capital Partners and three South Korean investors have bought the London headquarters of retailer Marks & Spencer for around US$321 million. The purchase of Waterside House, a 237,800 square foot office space, is Gaw Capital's fourth property deal in London this year. Asian investors are diversifying their portfolios by buying European properties, seeking steady yields of 5-6%. This deal marks the latest in a string of property acquisitions by Asian investors, following China's Ping An Insurance Group's acquisition of the Lloyds of London Building in July.

site_title: Patience has its rewards
summary: A rare and exclusive white burgundy, Musigny Blanc from Domaine Comte Georges de Vogue, is highly sought after due to its limited production and aging process. Currently sold as Bourgogne Blanc, it's expected to reappear as Musigny Blanc Grand Cru in 5 years when the vines mature. The article also highlights the rarity of other exclusive wines, such as the Harlan Estate 1994, and the importance of patience in wine collecting. The author emphasizes the rewards of long ageing and patience in the world of fine wines.

site_title: Productivity drive overshadows growth efforts at SMEs
summary: A survey of 10,000 SMEs in Singapore found that productivity, particularly manpower optimization, has overshadowed growth efforts. 62% plan to reduce foreign employees, leading to increased local staff costs, which is the top concern for 85% of SMEs. As a result, 44% of SMEs have a turnover of over $10 million, and only 7% expect double-digit growth. Fewer SMEs are pursuing expansion and have a business strategy, with 46% planning to do business overseas, down from 54% in 2012.

site_title: Changi Airport's passenger traffic up 3.2% in Oct
summary: Changi Airport's passenger traffic rose 3.2% in October, a slower pace of growth compared to recent months, with 4.41 million passengers passing through the airport. Cargo volumes edged up 1.8% to 157,400 tonnes. The airport's top 10 country markets, including Indonesia, Japan, and Malaysia, registered double-digit traffic growth. Global passenger growth is expected to hit 5% this year, while cargo growth is expected to be 0.9%.

site_title: IDA approves OpenNet sale with strings attached
summary: SingTel's $126 million acquisition of OpenNet by NetLink Trust has been approved by the Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) with conditions. SingTel must cut its stake in NetLink Trust to below 25% by April 2018, an extension from the original deadline. IDA has also established a monitoring board to ensure SingTel's interests are not prioritized over CityNet's, and CityNet will have "full independence" in making decisions for service offerings. The deal aims to streamline industry processes and ensure greater accountability with a single point of contact for fibre operations.

site_title: Fewer US homeowners with negative equity in Q2
summary: US homeowners with negative equity fell to 21% in Q2, the fastest pace on record, as home prices rose and supply shortages eased. This led to a 60.8% share of owners with at least 20% equity, making it easier for them to sell and buy new homes. The median existing home price rose 12.8% in Q2, with 10.8 million homeowners still underwater on their mortgages. Economists predict the real estate recovery will continue to support economic growth, with 8% price gains in 2014.

site_title: Hutchison sells house for HK$740m
summary: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd, controlled by Asia's richest man Li Ka-shing, sold a 6,863-square-foot house in Hong Kong's Victoria Peak area for HK$740 million, the second-highest paid for a property in the city. The sale price comes as the city's government has imposed extra property transaction taxes and tightened mortgage lending to curb home prices, now the world's highest. Luxury property prices are expected to drop 3% in the fourth quarter, with transactions declining to the lowest in almost two decades.

site_title: Three-minute digest
summary: A new hedge accounting model was released by the IASB in the UK, representing a substantial overhaul of the current system. The Draft Master Plan 2013 takes a more holistic approach to developing new activity clusters. COE premiums ended mixed, with small cars seeing price increases and big cars seeing decreases. OpenNet was fined $750,000 by the IDA for failing to meet service obligations. OUE Bayfront is expected to be sold for at least $1 billion. Singapore's domestic wholesale trade rose 5.1% in Q3. Indonesia's relations with Australia sank to a low.

site_title: China developers venture out in a big way
summary: Chinese property developers are investing billions of dollars in projects globally, driven by regulatory restrictions at home and concerns about the overheating Chinese property market. The developers are seeking opportunities in US cities, European markets, and Australia, with the US being the largest recipient of Chinese investment, at $2.88 billion this year. In exchange for relative safety, Chinese developers are accepting lower returns, with some settling for an internal rate of return of around 15%. The government's "hands off" approach has encouraged Chinese companies to venture abroad, with the government loosening rules governing direct investments overseas in 2009.

site_title: Hedge accounting sees substantial overhaul
summary: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) has released a new hedge-accounting model that aims to simplify and improve the accounting for risk-management activities. The new model, part of IFRS 9 Financial Instruments, aligns hedge accounting more closely with risk management and improves disclosures. The changes enable companies to better reflect their economic risk and simplify the accounting for hedging transactions. The new model applies to those that hedge non-financial risk and removes rigid requirements, allowing for greater flexibility. While the changes are expected to simplify hedge accounting, experts warn that more guidance may be needed to help organizations implement the new standard.

site_title: Hafary bets on S'pore housing as it opens $21.5m showroom
summary: Hafary Holdings, a tile supplier, has opened a new $21.5 million showroom in Singapore, targeting retail customers who account for 60-70% of the company's business. The six-storey building offers 20,000 square feet of space for the flagship showroom and will be leased out later. Despite a challenging housing market, Hafary CEO Eric Low believes public housing supply will provide some resilience and expects growth in other markets, including Vietnam. The company's multi-pronged strategy is expected to put it on solid ground.

site_title: SIIC Env buying stake in Shanghai company
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings has acquired a 50% stake in Shanghai Pucheng Thermal Power Energy for 530 million yuan (S$108.2 million), marking the company's first entry into Shanghai's waste-to-energy sector. The deal is expected to nearly double SIIC Environment's waste processing design capacity to 2,000 tonnes per day. The acquisition is seen as an opportunity for SIIC Environment to become a fully integrated environmental player in China, with the company's earnings per share expected to increase.

site_title: Mixed outcome in latest COE tender
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums ended mixed, with Category A (small cars) rising 3.3% to $74,991, while Category B (big cars) fell 3.9% to $79,300. The premium for goods vehicles and buses decreased to $55,002, and motorcycles inched up to $1,712. The Land Transport Authority plans to recategorize COEs based on engine power in February, potentially affecting certain car models.

site_title: The latest news from Bloomberg is about big changes
summary: Bloomberg News underwent significant layoffs, with reporters being escorted from the building, in an effort to streamline the newsroom and focus on high-impact content. Editor-in-chief Matt Winkler's departure marks a shift towards a more business-oriented approach, with a greater emphasis on profitability and client service. The move is seen as a response to the growing influence of Michael Bloomberg's co-founder Tom Secunda, who prioritizes profitability over investigative journalism and broad coverage. The layoffs are part of a broader reorganization, with Josh Tyrangiel taking over Bloomberg Businessweek and Bloomberg Media CEO Justin Smith overseeing the entire organization.

site_title: CMA in 2.65b yuan deal for Guangzhou mall
summary: CAPITAMALLS Asia (CMA) is acquiring a new shopping mall in Guangzhou, China for approximately 2.65 billion yuan (S$541 million). The mall, located in Baiyun District, is expected to be completed by Q4 2014. CMA's CEO, Lim Beng Chee, stated that the acquisition marks the company's strategic entry into a first-tier city in South China, with plans to leverage its existing team in the region. This is CMA's first purchase in Guangzhou and its 62nd shopping mall in 37 cities in China.

site_title: Higher full-year growth forecast; Q3 GDP up 5.8%
summary: The Singapore government raised its full-year growth forecast to 3.5-4% due to a surprisingly better year than initially anticipated. This upward revision from the initial 1-3% forecast range is attributed to an upward revision in August. However, growth for 2014 is still projected to be "modest" due to risks from labour shortages and uncertain outlooks for the US, eurozone, and China.

images.alt_text: This year is turning out to be a surprisingly better year for the Singapore economy than what its start suggested, but 2014 is likely to settle back to another year of "modest" growth - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Stiff competition muddies the water
summary: Singapore-listed companies competing in China's water treatment market face stiff competition and squeezed margins, leading to lower revenues and earnings. The Chinese government's 430 billion yuan investment in the sector has attracted foreign companies, while private companies, including those from Singapore, struggle to maintain profitability. Despite this, some companies, such as Hyflux, have reported better earnings due to newly acquired plants. Experts warn that the water sector's dependence on infrastructure spending makes it vulnerable to economic downturns, but a potential economic growth acceleration in China could alleviate concerns.

site_title: Marina South likely to be pick of the bunch
summary: Marina South is likely to attract the most interest among three new housing sites in Singapore's Draft Master Plan 2013, due to its transformative potential and prime location. The 21.5-hectare site will feature 9,000 private homes and an underground mall, with development slated for 2017/2018. Analysts praise the site's convenience to the CBD and its potential for high-quality recreational spaces. Other sites, including Kampong Bugis and Holland Village extension, also have strong attributes and will yield around 14,500 homes, with development expected to start in 2016 and 2015 respectively.

site_title: Qantas-VA row over 'takeover' turns ugly
summary: Qantas and Virgin Australia (VA) are embroiled in a dispute over foreign ownership, with Qantas CEO Alan Joyce accusing VA of a "virtual takeover" by foreign airlines. VA CEO John Borghetti denies the allegations, calling them "offensive and absurd." Borghetti is considering suing Joyce for defamation, while Qantas stands by its claims. The dispute follows a capital raising by VA that could leave 72% of the airline in foreign hands, sparking concerns about an "unfair playing field" and destabilization of the domestic aviation industry.

site_title: Government fines OpenNet $750,000
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) has fined OpenNet $750,000 for failing to meet its universal service obligation and quality of service standards in the first half of 2013. The fine includes a $550,000 penalty for not reaching its service obligation and a $200,000 fine for falling short of QOS standards. The failure affected around 120,000 residential premises and 760 non-residential buildings, with OpenNet accepting fibre orders from all homes and businesses since July.

site_title: Rex unit gets nod for Norway offshore deal
summary: Rex International Holding's subsidiary, Lime Petroleum Norway, has received approval from Norway's Ministry of Petroleum and Energy to acquire 10% stakes in two offshore licences, PL 707 and PL 708, in the Barents Sea. The licences, awarded in June, cover areas of approximately 982 sq km and 507 sq km. The acquisition is expected to become effective on November 29. Lime will work with operators Edison International Norway Branch and Lundin Norway AS on the concessions.

site_title: A more people-centric Master Plan
summary: Singapore's Draft Master Plan 2013 takes a more holistic approach to urban planning, focusing on quality of life and community engagement. The plan aims to create a more liveable environment and encourages green spaces, while maintaining a stronger emphasis on economics. However, plot ratios were left largely unchanged, sparking concerns that the government may be working towards a longer timeline to phase in increased plot ratios. Experts suggest that the government should focus on expanding land and providing communal spaces, rather than increasing plot ratios, to cater to the growing population and manufacturing sector.

site_title: OCBC's children accounts up 50%
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 50% growth in children accounts opened over the last three years, with Sunday banking services contributing to the surge. The bank attributes this growth to its Sunday Banking service, which includes a Children's Activity Corner and dedicated teller counter. As one of two banks managing Child Development Accounts under Singapore's Baby Bonus Scheme, OCBC's Sunday service is in its seventh year, making banking enjoyable for young children.

site_title: China may speed up freeing of yuan currency
summary: China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan has hinted at speeding up currency reform, potentially widening the yuan's trading band and allowing markets to set its exchange rate more freely. This could lead to a larger appreciation of the yuan versus the US dollar. However, the central bank has not provided a specific timetable for the changes, and some analysts caution that the pace of financial reform may be slow due to concerns about volatile capital flows. The reforms aim to shift China's economy from investment- and exports-led growth to consumption and services.

site_title: Funds go on home buying spree in US
summary: A large investment fund, led by Australian investor Alan Dixon, has purchased over 538 homes in the US, primarily in Brooklyn and surrounding areas, as part of a trend of private equity firms buying single-family homes to rent out. These firms aim for steady returns, unlike the 2000s real estate bubble. Critics argue they crowd out first-time homebuyers, but proponents say they're gobbling up overhanging home inventories, supporting and increasing overall home prices. The median home price in Brooklyn has soared 12% in the past year, pricing out lower-income families.

site_title: Goldman seeks to halt Oei Hong Leong's lawsuit
summary: Goldman Sachs International has requested a court in Singapore to halt a lawsuit filed by tycoon Oei Hong Leong, claiming the company misled him into making leveraged trades that the yen would fall against the Brazilian real. Oei is seeking US$31.7 million in trading losses, plus interest, alleging fraudulent representations made by Goldman Sachs. The company plans to defend the lawsuit, which it considers without merit, and has filed for private and confidential arbitration in London, but Oei's lawyer plans to challenge the arbitration bid.

site_title: S'pore Airshow's order value 'unlikely to top Dubai's'
summary: The Singapore Airshow, set to take place from February 11 to 16, 2014, has seen strong demand for space with 95% of exhibition space already leased. While it's unlikely to surpass Dubai's order value, which reached $200 billion, organizers are optimistic about bookings. Boeing secured over 340 orders worth $101 billion, and Airbus booked 160 orders worth $44 billion. The show will feature static displays of aircraft, including the Boeing Dreamliner, and coincide with high-level conferences catering to the global aviation industry.

site_title: KL property players question assessment fee hikes
summary: KL property players and experts question the proposed 100-300% increase in assessment fees by the Kuala Lumpur City Council, citing that the fees should be based on annual rental values, not real estate values. They argue that rental yields have shrunk due to rising property prices, making the proposed hikes "misconceived." Experts suggest the council should review the rate, not the assessment, and that the current rate of 6% for residential properties is already high. The proposed hikes are seen as a potential "punishment" for residents who voted for the opposition coalition in the recent general election.

site_title: Nine-months and Q3 results ended Sept 2013
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Companies reported Q3 results, with Creative Technology warning of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Spain to appeal for damages over oil spill
summary: Spain plans to appeal for damages over the 2002 Prestige tanker disaster, which caused one of Europe's worst environmental disasters, killing tens of thousands of seabirds. A court acquitted the ship's crew and a top Spanish maritime official, ruling that deficient maintenance had failed to detect a structural fault. The government aims to recover the 368 million euros in costs associated with the disaster, with the appeal focusing on civil liability rather than criminal responsibility. The ship's captain was sentenced to nine months in jail for resisting attempts to tow the wreck away from shore.

site_title: Billion $ tag for OUE Bayfront
summary: OUE Ltd is seeking to sell its office and retail development, OUE Bayfront, for at least $1 billion to its newly proposed Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT), OUE C-Reit. The sale includes $696.9 million in cash and $308.1 million in units of OUE C-Reit. OUE aims to raise up to $700 million through the REIT's initial public offering. The sale will help pay down debt of $376.6 million.

site_title: OGX, Petronas may go to arbitration
summary: Petronas has rescinded a US$850 million agreement to buy a 40% stake in two Brazilian oil blocks from OGX, citing the company's failure to restructure its US$5 billion debt. OGX may consider arbitration against Petronas, which had set the debt restructuring as a pre-condition for the deal. The deal's collapse could spell the end for OGX, which is facing bankruptcy. Petronas is also scaling down its overseas investments, including a US$5.2 billion buyout in Canada's Progress Energy Resources.

site_title: Malaysia's economy remains resilient
summary: Malaysia's economy has shown resilience despite sluggish growth among its neighbors, with the third-quarter growth accelerating to 5% on strong domestic demand and a turnaround in exports. Real GDP growth for 2013 is likely to fall within the government's projection of 4.5-5%. Economists are bullish, predicting growth between 5-5.5% for 2014. The current-account deficit has recovered, and yearly surpluses of RM35 billion to RM40 billion are expected over the next two years. However, the government faces challenges, including a 6% goods and services tax and a budget deficit that needs to be addressed to achieve a surplus.

site_title: ICBC yuan bond makes stunning debut
summary: The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China's (ICBC) Singapore branch successfully debuted with a 2 billion yuan, two-year yuan bond, priced at 3.2%. The issue received strong demand, with orders hitting 5.2 billion yuan. This is the first Chinese entity to issue a yuan bond cleared in Singapore, and the largest yuan bond issuance by a Chinese entity in the country. ICBC plans to increase its Renminbi (RMB) assets to 70% of total assets within three years, driven by its RMB strength and growing demand for yuan funding.

site_title: Thai developer Hemaraj to sell its first property fund
summary: Thai developer Hemaraj Land & Development Pcl plans to raise 4.5 billion baht through its first property fund to finance new projects, including a new industrial park in Rayong province. The fund will be backed by rental revenue from factories and warehouses, and will help the company pay debt. Hemaraj joins other Thai billionaires in selling funds backed by real estate to tap local demand for investments offering higher yields than bank deposits or bonds.

site_title: US$23b Emirates order injects new life into Airbus A380
summary: Emirates Airlines has ordered 50 Airbus A380 jets worth $23 billion, ending doubts about the aircraft's viability. The order, the largest to date, is expected to boost Airbus' fortunes and fill the backlog of 259 planes ordered since 2000. Emirates' president Tim Clark stated the airline is committed to the A380, with plans to take more if possible. The deal is seen as a significant turnaround for the A380, which had faced concerns over demand due to economic times.

site_title: JTC factories in Kadut, Yew Tee, Kranji face relocation
summary: Singapore's industrial property landlord and developer JTC factories in Kadut, Yew Tee, and Kranji areas may face relocation due to changes in the country's Master Plan. The plan, still in draft stage, will decide how land will be used in the future. JTC will assist firms through the relocation process and has offered to extend leases until 2020 for 116 firms, provided they meet certain criteria such as productivity increment and value added. The affected firms, including those in the furniture and timber industries, have welcomed the offer, giving them a timeline to plan for the future.

site_title: German home approvals highest in 9 years
summary: Germany saw its highest home approvals in 9 years, with 202,100 building permits issued from January to September, a 13.5% increase from the same period in 2012. Low interest rates and the eurozone crisis have driven demand for property over financial assets, with investors betting on real estate. However, there is no risk of a housing bubble forming, according to the chief economist at Germany's HDB construction industry group. The industry aims to meet a 2% turnover increase, but is expected to end the year with a minimal gain or loss.

site_title: GDF, Total, H&F plan Feb IPO for LNG membrane unit: report
summary: French utility GDF Suez, oil firm Total, and private equity fund Hellman & Friedman plan a February initial public offering (IPO) for their jointly-owned unit GTT, the world's No 1 maker of cryogenic hull linings for LNG tankers. GTT could be valued at up to US$2.4 billion, with shareholders planning to sell a portion of their stakes. The company has 70% of the market for high-tech alloy membranes lining LNG carriers, and has earned a net profit of 30 million euros last year.

site_title: Correction
summary: A correction was issued for an article published on November 19, 2013, stating that Rajan Menon has not left RHTLaw Taylor Wessing, contrary to the impression given. The original article was about the firm going international to compete locally.

site_title: OECD lowers global growth forecast
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has lowered its global growth forecast to 2.7% for this year and 3.6% for 2014, citing weaker prospects in emerging economies and heightened risks in the euro-area banking sector and Japan's fiscal situation. Global growth is projected to pick up to 3.9% in 2015. The OECD recommends policy actions to counter downside risks and emphasizes the need for structural reforms in Japan, the euro area, and emerging economies to strengthen growth prospects and debt dynamics.

site_title: Air NZ share sale adds NZ$365m to govt coffers
summary: New Zealand's government raised NZ$365 million from the sale of shares in Air New Zealand Ltd, reducing its stake in the national carrier to 53% from 73%. The sale, part of the country's asset sales program, aims to fund infrastructure and reduce debt. The program has now raised NZ$3.93 billion, with a non-binding referendum on divestments set to open on Nov 22. The government is "very happy" with the price achieved for Air New Zealand, with domestic retail investors purchasing 41% of the shares.

site_title: United Engineers plans exit offer to delist WBL
summary: United Engineers plans to offer a buyout to delist tech and property group WBL from the Singapore Exchange, citing greater control and management flexibility. The offer price is $4.45 per stock unit, with remaining shareholders to be offered an exit in cash. WBL's shares have been suspended from trading since May 30, and the company had previously indicated it would not preserve the listing status. The delisting proposal has been approved by WBL's board, and an application will be made to the SGX for a waiver on the need for shareholder approval.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Civmec secures $65 million in new contracts for an air gas liquefaction plant and structural steel work for Holcim's concrete plants in Australia. Thai Village Holdings reports a 21% decline in full-year profit to $1.31 million, with total revenue decreasing by 16%. Pacific Radiance's joint venture plans to issue up to 193.3 million new shares, with funds earmarked for fleet upgrade and expansion.

site_title: Vector putting $50m into Seletar facility
