Companies are prioritizing innovative solutions, employee engagement, and talent development to stay ahead in a competitive market. With Singapore's strong economy and growing demand for cloud-connected services, businesses are expected to focus on delivering greater sales velocity and innovation in the year ahead.

site_title: Most S'pore servers are not virtualised
summary: Most servers in Singapore are not virtualised, with only 18% of x86 servers virtualised, according to VMware. In contrast, 80% of Australia's servers are virtualised, and the global average is below 50%. Legacy applications are a major barrier to virtualisation, but companies are shifting to third-party clouds for cost savings and flexibility. Singapore has the second-highest cloud adoption rate in the Asia-Pacific region, with 51% of businesses using cloud services. VMware is promoting its virtualisation technology to enable in-house data centres to function as cloud service providers.

site_title: Abenomics not game changing: economist
summary: A report by Standard & Poor's chief global economist Paul Sheard suggests that Japan's economic growth rate under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics policy is unlikely to reach 2% due to the country's shrinking population and workforce. Sheard calls for more radical measures, such as raising the retirement age, encouraging immigration, and increasing birth rates, to boost growth. He warns that Japan's potential growth rate is set to decline steadily over the foreseeable future, and that the current policies may not be enough to reverse the country's demographic decline.

site_title: Making their mark for BT
summary: BT journalists won honours at the 14th SIAS Investors's Choice Awards, including Andrea Soh (Most Promising Journalist of the Year), Cai Haoxiang (Investor Education Journalist of the Year), and Kenneth Lim (Special Award). Teh Hooi Ling, who left BT to become a fund manager, received a Special Award. This marks the last time BT journalists will be recognized at the awards due to Teh's departure.

site_title: At a glance
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower after President Trump imposed fresh tariffs on Canada. Companies like Creative Technology warned of lower-than-expected H2 revenue, and London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. In Indonesia, a Trafigura employee was detained in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, while MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Serving up the flavours of Italy
summary: La Strada, a newly re-opened Italian trattoria in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with its $28 set lunches, which provide generous portions of dishes such as sautéed mushrooms, squid, and grilled tiger prawns. The restaurant's pricing strategy is effective, but it may need to refine its trattoria concept to break the perception that Italian restaurants must be authentic with an Italian chef. Despite this, La Strada's menu offers a range of dishes, including pasta, seafood, and meat options, that showcase the restaurant's ability to infuse humble ingredients with fine-dining flair.

site_title: ADB to lend India US$10b over next 5 years
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has agreed to lend India $10 billion over the next five years, with the potential for much more if an innovative scheme to tap into institutional investor funds succeeds. The ADB will set aside some funds for credit guarantees, allowing Indian pension and insurance funds to deploy their resources in financing projects. This move aims to address India's infrastructure financing needs, which are estimated to be around $8 trillion over the next decade, and is seen as crucial for the country's economic growth.

site_title: Savouring the good ole days
summary: Penang, Malaysia, is a destination that evokes nostalgia for baby boomers, with its sights, smells, and tastes transporting visitors back to the Singapore of the 1960s and 1970s. The town has undergone modernization and gentrification, but certain areas still retain their charm. Visitors can experience authentic street food, including signature dishes like laksa, meat porridge, and fried kway teow. Local eateries, such as the Penang fried kway teow stall at Jalan Kuala Kangsar Street Market and the curry fish head at Sri Siam, offer a unique culinary experience.

site_title: Venture Q3 profit climbs 7.7% to $35.1m
summary: Venture Corporation reported a 7.7% year-over-year increase in third-quarter net profit to $35.1 million, despite a 3.4% decline in revenue to $588.5 million. The retail store solutions and industrial products segment accounted for 30% of revenue. The company attributed its profit growth to operational excellence, lean manufacturing, and productivity improvements, despite challenging industry conditions and rising minimum wage levels. Earnings per share decreased to 12.8 cents, and the group generated $21.2 million in cash from operations.

site_title: Pacific Radiance's Indonesian affiliate plans Jakarta listing
summary: Pacific Radiance's Indonesian affiliate, PT Logindo, plans to list its shares in Jakarta, driven by rising investor interest in vessel operators expanding in Indonesia's offshore energy sector. The IPO will benefit from Indonesia's cabotage laws, which limit supply and drive up chartering costs. Pacific Radiance, which owns a 49% stake in Logindo, expects the IPO to raise funds for expansion and join a growing number of listed offshore oilfield service providers in Indonesia. The listing follows other Singapore-listed companies, including Marco Polo Marine Ltd and ASL Marine Holdings Ltd.

site_title: SPH journalists bag SIAS awards
summary: SPH journalists have won several awards from the Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) for their work in financial journalism. Andrea Soh of The Business Times was named Most Promising Journalist of the Year, while Cai Haoxiang won the Investor Education Journalist of the Year prize. Other winners include Teh Hooi Ling and Kenneth Lim, with SPH also receiving awards for transparency and community investor education. The recognition highlights the company's commitment to financial journalism and transparency.

site_title: London Gateway port receives its first vessel
summary: London Gateway port, owned by DP World Ltd, has received its first vessel, the MOL Caledon, marking the completion of a decade-long project. Located 40 km east of London, the port can handle 3.5 million 20-foot containers per year and is designed to accommodate the world's largest ships. The port's proximity to major UK population centers reduces transportation costs and is expected to become one of Europe's busiest container terminals. DP World spent £1.5 billion developing the site, which is two-thirds closer to half London than the Port of Felixstowe.

site_title: MND delays move of headquarters to Jem
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) has delayed its move to Jurong East, but its statutory boards, Agri-Food & Veterinary Authority of Singapore (AVA) and Building and Construction Authority (BCA), will proceed with relocation to the Jem project as planned in 2014. The 11-level office space will receive a Temporary Occupation Permit by year's end. MND's headquarters will move in phases, taking into account market conditions and development pace. This will create a strategic cluster of associated ministries at Jurong Lake District, supporting regional growth.

site_title: First trading day becomes one big Twitterverse party for #TwitterIPO
summary: Twitter's first trading session on November 7, 2013, saw the company's stock price surge 73% to $45.10 on the New York Stock Exchange, more than doubling its IPO price of $26. Investors eagerly snapped up shares, making a small group of men nearly twice as rich as they were on the previous day. The sudden price increase was a fitting culmination of the "Twitterverse party" that had unfolded throughout the trading day.

site_title: Bad weather takes its toll on KrisEnergy
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-based oil and gas exploration and production group, reported a total comprehensive loss of US$3.55 million for its third quarter, down from a profit of US$681,000 last year. The company's revenue fell 37% to US$13.6 million due to bad weather and production disruptions, including the closure of an oilfield in Indonesia. Despite these challenges, KrisEnergy expects its fourth-quarter results to be unaffected, thanks to a new production platform installation in Thailand.

site_title: Call for broad fund framework
summary: PwC Singapore is calling for a broad fund framework to attract non-retail funds, such as hedge funds and private equity, to invest in emerging markets (EMs). The proposed framework, expected to be released in December, aims to provide more flexibility and competitiveness for the industry. Currently, funds often domicile in the Cayman Islands, but PwC suggests a corporatised investment vehicle, similar to those in Europe, to cater to the industry's needs. The new framework is expected to spur more fund managers to set up operations in Singapore, contributing to the economy's growth and employment.

site_title: UOL's Q3 earnings up 6% at $93.5m
summary: UOL Group's third-quarter net profit rose 6% to $93.5 million, driven by higher profit margins and joint-venture company profits. Revenue declined 6% to $261.8 million due to completed property developments. Gross profit margin improved to 50% and earnings per share rose to 12.14 cents. The group expects modest office rental growth and a stable retail leasing market, but notes that hotel performance may be affected by increasing supply and slower visitor growth.

site_title: Hold back the scalpel
summary: Surgery should be the last resort for those with deteriorating health conditions, especially when exercise and natural methods can help. Pilates, yoga, and therapeutic essential oils can improve common ailments such as pelvic organ prolapse, low back pain, and sciatica. Pelvic floor exercises, core strength development, and proper biomechanical alignment can alleviate symptoms. Essential oils like Eucalyptus, Copaiba, and Frankincense have anti-inflammatory effects and can be used to treat sinusitis, arthritic pain, and other conditions. These natural methods can be used before surgery to improve outcomes and reduce the need for invasive procedures.

site_title: MBS deals the aces to local firms when awarding contracts
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) has continued to award most of its contracts to local firms, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), since its opening in 2010. In 2013, MBS awarded 93% of its procurement contracts to Singapore-based companies, with over half going to local SMEs. The integrated resort aims to benefit the local community and ensure that local enterprises grow along with its development in Singapore.

site_title: SIAS chief calls for heavy fines on those who breach listing rules
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association Singapore (SIAS) is calling for stricter regulations on companies that breach listing rules, including heavy fines for individuals involved. The organization cited the recent penny stock price collapses triggered by Asiasons, Blumont, and LionGold, which led to a wave of selling in other companies. SIAS president David Gerald urged regulators to review instances where unusual price movements affect shareholder approvals and for listed companies to disclose recent queries from regulators when announcing acquisitions and disposals.

site_title: Grand dame made over
summary: Tandoor, a renowned Indian fine dining restaurant in Singapore, has undergone a facelift after 28 years. The revamped restaurant features a modern ambiance with clean lines, white and golden yellow hues, and traditional Indian elements. The culinary team, led by new head chef Sujit Naik, has expanded the menu to include lighter dishes and international flavors. Classic dishes like butter chicken and cinnamon smoked mamali seekh kebab remain, while new dishes incorporate ingredients like American corn kebabs and Thai-inspired chicken murg kebab.

site_title: Rock on rollerskates
summary: The musical "Starlight Express" by Andrew Lloyd Webber is coming to Singapore's Marina Bay Sands Grand Theatre from Nov 13 to Nov 24. The show, which features 28 cast members performing on roller-skates, tells the story of a child's toy trains racing for the title of the "fastest engine in the world". Choreographer Arlene Philips and director Trevor Nunn have adapted the original West End production for the global tour, with skating consultant Michal Fraley ensuring safety and artistry. Tickets range from $65 to $780.

site_title: IDA: PMO and Istana websites not hacked, but compromised
summary: The websites of the Prime Minister's Office (PMO) and Istana in Singapore were compromised, but not hacked, after a vulnerability in the Google Search bar embedded on their subpages was exploited. The attacks, which occurred on Thursday and Friday, were designed to trick users into visiting fake websites resembling the PMO or Istana sites with malicious content. Both main websites are still functioning, and restoration of the compromised subpages is underway. An investigation by the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore and the police is ongoing.

site_title: Surge in US structured note bets on EMs
summary: US investors purchased the most structured notes betting on emerging-market companies in two years, with $117.7 million sold in October. The surge is attributed to a 16-day partial government shutdown, which boosted foreign stocks on the prospect of a weaker dollar. The Federal Reserve's accommodative monetary policy, led by Chairman Ben Bernanke, has bolstered emerging markets by weakening the dollar and keeping US bond yields low. Investors are using leverage to amplify returns on emerging-markets ETFs, with sales falling 18% to $383.8 million through October.

site_title: Younger buyers spice up Bentley's cars
summary: Bentley's car sales in Singapore have seen a shift towards younger buyers, with 15% of 110 sold cars in the first nine months of 2013 being purchased by those under 40. These buyers prefer bold, bright colors, unlike the understated schemes preferred by older buyers. The luxury marque has seen a steady sales increase, with a focus on tradition and craftsmanship, and is considering a plug-in hybrid electric car in the future. Bentley's racing activities are also set to resume, with a test race in Abu Dhabi on December 13.

site_title: Washington state extends US$9b tax breaks for Boeing
summary: The Washington state legislature has passed a measure to extend nearly $9 billion in tax breaks for Boeing through 2040 to entice the company to locate production of its 777X jet in the Seattle area. The tax breaks, combined with a proposed labor contract, are key to keeping the production local. However, if the machinists union votes down the contract, Boeing may consider other locations, including South Carolina, Texas, and Utah. Industry observers see Japan as a contender to build the 777X's wings, further complicating the state's efforts to secure the production.

site_title: Upcoming SUV will target global market
summary: Bentley is set to launch its first SUV by 2016, targeting a global market with a fresh design while retaining its strong luxury DNA. The vehicle will cater to various consumers, including soccer moms, sporty types, and those in developing countries. Head of Exterior Design, Sangyup Lee, emphasizes the importance of making the SUV "timeless and classic," while respecting the brand's heritage. The final design is still under wraps, but Lee expects to sign off on it soon, citing customer feedback as a key factor in its development.

site_title: Market ends week on a dismal note
summary: Singapore shares ended the week on a dismal note, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing down 24.85 points or about 1% to 3,177.25, despite solid third-quarter results and new contracts in the offshore & marine sector. Heavyweight bank stocks, Wilmar, and ST Engineering (ST Engg) led the losses, while only SIA Engineering rose 3 cents to $5.09 on strong interim earnings. Analysts attributed the market's lacklustre trading to institutional buying switching to more interesting markets in Thailand and Indonesia, with thin volume expected to continue into next week.

site_title: RBS wants stronger link between its Asia, UK ops
summary: RBS aims to strengthen its connection between its UK and Asia operations, with only 10% of its Asian business linked to the UK. CEO Ross McEwan emphasized the need to support UK customers in Asia, Asian clients in the UK, and attract new customers in the region. The bank will focus on its strengths in debt capital markets, cash management, and risk management. McEwan also denied plans to sell RBS's private banking business, Coutts, and its Asian segment, stating it is not for sale. The bank will review all ongoing businesses and speed up the sale of its US subsidiary.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: A "melt-up" in global markets has investors at a crossroads, with shares on Wall Street and in several European countries rising significantly in the past three months. The Ministry of National Development has delayed its move to Jurong East, while the ADB has agreed to lend India $10 billion over five years. Economist Shinzo Abe's Abenomics plan is deemed unlikely to boost Japan's growth rate without more radical measures. Meanwhile, Dynaforce has entered a joint venture with Starpool to expand its Asian footprint, and Petronas is seeking to cut its stake in a Canadian LNG project.

site_title: Housing memories
summary: Lawrence and Melanie Lee, a sentimental couple, have amassed a vast collection of personal items, including family photos, cross-stitch, and childhood memorabilia, which they proudly display in their home. Despite having a large collection, the family's semi-detached home remains clutter-free due to their knowledge of home design and storage. The couple, who own a building company, designed their home with ease of maintenance in mind, featuring automatic doors, a lap pool, and a rooftop dining space. The family's children also have their own unique collections, including stamps, soft toys, and bird nests, which they display throughout the home.

site_title: M'sia holds rate, but may hike it early next year as inflation rises
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, held its overnight policy rate at 3% despite rising inflation, driven by an oil price hike in September. The bank acknowledged inflation will edge up but tempered expectations with a stable external price environment and moderate domestic demand pressures. The decision was seen as a cautious move to avoid downside risks to growth. Malaysia's trade data for September surpassed forecasts, with a trade surplus of RM8.7 billion, alleviating concerns about a current account deficit. Economists expect interest rates to be hiked by at least 25 basis points early next year.

site_title: Far East H-Trust's Q3 DPU falls below forecast
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (Far East H-Trust) reported a distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.41 cents for the third quarter ended September, falling short of its forecast of 1.53 cents. The trust's income available for distribution missed its forecast by 7.4% due to industry-wide price competition and a stronger Singapore dollar. Despite this, retail and office spaces performed well, with high occupancies and stable rentals. The trust plans to upgrade 10% of its hotel rooms and serviced residence units in the next 12 months.

site_title: Higher demand lifts Valuetronics' Q2 earnings to HK$39.6m
summary: Valuetronics Holdings posted a fiscal Q2 net profit of HK$39.6 million, up 14.8% from HK$34.5 million, driven by higher demand from industrial and consumer electronics customers. Revenue rose 6.1% to a record HK$632 million. For the half-year period, earnings grew 151% to HK$72.9 million. The company expects to achieve profitability growth despite ongoing costs and wage pressures in China, with plans to increase capacity and productivity.

site_title: Will UK tax foreign-owned property sales? Osborne to announce decision on Dec 4
summary: UK Treasury Minister Sajid Javid hinted that foreigners selling British homes may face an unprecedented tax on property sales, which Chancellor George Osborne is considering to curb rising house prices in London and the south-east. The tax, potentially a capital gains tax, would target non-UK residents selling luxury properties, amid pressure from the International Monetary Fund and critics of Osborne's support for home ownership. An announcement is expected on December 4 in the Autumn Statement.

site_title: Curry favour
summary: Indian fine dining in Singapore is undergoing a modernist transformation, shedding its traditional image and calorie-laden reputation. New restaurants, such as Pind Balluchi and Earl of Hindh, are incorporating fresh herbs, lighter flavors, and modernist cooking techniques to appeal to a broader audience. Industry stalwarts, like Rang Mahal, are also adapting to changing tastes, with menus featuring regional flavors and healthier options. The trend is driven by health-conscious diners and a desire for novel culinary experiences, with chefs aiming to balance traditional Indian cuisine with modern twists and international influences.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported varying Q3 earnings. SIIC Env Q3 profit jumped 34% to $7.8 million, while Bonvests Holdings doubled its net profit to $5.6 million. Wee Hur Holdings saw its nine-month net profit rise to $13.1 million. However, OUE's Q3 earnings declined 43.9% due to lower occupancy, and FE Orchard's net profit fell to $5.3 million without a one-time gain. A-Sonic Aviation's aircraft-leasing business continues to grow with the placement of its fourth single-aisle plane.

site_title: Breezy chic Indian dining
summary: The Earl of Hindh, a modern Indian restaurant in Sentosa Cove, Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with traditional flavors and personalized service. Founded by five friends who sought a non-conventional setting for fine Indian cuisine, the restaurant is led by head chef Jaswant Singh Negi, who brings luxury hotel experience from India. The menu features a range of dishes, including grilled starters, curries, and desserts, with a focus on reviving traditional Indian cooking techniques. The restaurant also offers a selection of premium single malt whiskies and hosts whisky and Indian food pairing dinners.

site_title: MBS, T3, University Town on show in NYC
summary: Singapore's iconic developments, such as Marina Bay Sands, Changi Airport Terminal 3, and the National University of Singapore's University Town master plan, are on display at an exhibition in New York City as part of the city's architecture and design month, Archtober. The exhibition, titled "Practical Utopias," explores architectural advancements in Singapore, Hong Kong, Seoul, Shanghai, and Tokyo, highlighting similarities and differences in urban planning and design. The exhibition aims to broaden perspectives and provide a fresh look at Asian cities, emphasizing the importance of learning from global best practices to keep cities globally competitive.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a 41% drop in Q2 net profit to $9 million, despite revenue increasing to $113.3 million. Yeo Hiap Seng saw a 12.9% rise in revenue and a 376% increase in net profit to $22.3 million due to asset sale gains. LionGold warned of an H1 pre-tax loss due to care and maintenance costs and unrealized losses on financial assets. Cosco Corporation secured a letter of intent for two contracts worth over $200 million each.

site_title: ST Engineering Q3 earnings down 10%
summary: ST Engineering reported a 10.3% year-on-year decline in net profit to $131.4 million for the third quarter, driven by a 11% drop in land systems business revenue and a 33% decline in others category revenue. The aerospace sector's profit before tax was 6% lower due to fewer project milestone completions. Revenue was flat at $1.55 billion, with commercial sales accounting for 63% of group revenue. The company's order book is expected to be recognized in the remaining months of the year, providing a cushion against market volatility.

site_title: Bondholders rattled as F&N plays tough
summary: Bondholders of Fraser and Neave (F&N) are upset over the company's offer to waive default terms on their notes in exchange for allowing the listing of its property business, Frasers Centrepoint (FCL). The offer, which would allow F&N to split off FCL without triggering a technical default, has been met with outrage due to the low price, with some bonds trading at 109% of par value. F&N has threatened to enter technical default if the necessary waivers are not obtained, which could set a precedent worldwide.

site_title: Blending tech and art
summary: Marc Sadler, a French industrial designer, has had a successful career spanning over five decades, creating products that have improved people's lives. His work includes designing a motorcycle back protector that saved a person's life, and his pieces are now in the permanent collection at the Museum of Modern Art. Sadler's approach combines technology and art, and he is known for his ability to understand the market and work with clients to create products that make life easier or better. He has worked with prominent brands such as Nike, Adidas, and Foscarini, and has received letters from strangers thanking him for his life-saving designs.

site_title: In business for the busy
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Services catering to busy professionals are on the rise, offering solutions to save time. Independent online grocer Redmart and reservation service Reservation Commerce are examples of businesses capitalizing on the demand. Meanwhile, Brainy Moves, a mind-body exercise program, teaches 10-minute daily workouts to improve brain function and physical fitness. Jublia Match, a web-based application, facilitates networking at events by curating delegates based on networking needs. Mothernist, a self-help site, provides goal-oriented advice and videos on mental health and well-being for working women, aiming to raise awareness and improve emotional well-being.

site_title: DBS offers to trade new notes for $800m in preference shares
summary: DBS Group Holdings is offering to buy back $800 million of outstanding preference shares for new notes with a higher payout and shorter tenor, making them Basel III compliant and qualifying as Tier 1 capital. Existing note holders can exchange at par for the new notes, which pay out 4.7-4.9% and have a call date in November 2019. The move is seen as "investor friendly" and attractive relative to a recent perpetual issue by United Overseas Bank, with interest rates likely to remain low for the next 2-3 years.

site_title: Upscale bar and grill
summary: Pind Balluchi, a 24-outlet chain of casual eateries from India, has opened its first overseas outpost in Singapore's Clarke Quay. The upscale bar and grill features international cocktails and offers traditional Indian dishes with a twist, such as pounded pathar lamb kebab and minced galouti kebab. Head chef Nishesh Mani Tripathi aims to expand the restaurant with two to three more outlets in Singapore, potentially incorporating open kitchen concepts, fusion restaurants, or Indian tapas bars.

site_title: Nera Telecom's Q3 profit falls 42.1% as costs soar
summary: Nera Telecom reported a 42.1% drop in Q3 net profit to $3.3 million due to soaring operating expenses, with distribution and selling costs increasing 23.7% to $7.2 million. The group's telecommunications segment saw a 28.7% increase in revenue, while its infocomm division fell 9.7%. The company's 9-month net profit rose 26.4% to $19.6 million, excluding a $7.1 million negative goodwill from an acquisition.

site_title: Singapore, Taiwan sign economic agreement to boost exports
summary: Singapore and Taiwan have signed an economic partnership agreement, ASTEP, which will eliminate import duties and taxes for almost all of Singapore's exports to Taiwan, a move expected to boost exports and deepen trade and investment flows between the two countries. The agreement, which covers areas like investment, e-commerce, and customs procedures, is Taiwan's first economic partnership agreement with an Asean country and its first with one of its top 10 trading partners.

site_title: Indonesia must head off industrial unrest
summary: Indonesia narrowly avoided industrial unrest as only a few thousand workers went on strike to demand a 50% wage increase, despite a call from the Confederation of Indonesian Workers Union. The government is concerned about the impact on foreign investors and the country's slowing economic growth. The Indonesian Employers Association warned that a 50% wage increase would lead to job losses and relocation. The central bank has forecast inflation to rise to 9.8% at the end of the year, and the government may consider imposing a compulsory system of mediation and arbitration.

site_title: Hot and ready to pop
summary: St Jerome's Laneway Festival, a boutique music festival, is on track to make Singapore its destination venue, with attendance growing 30% year-on-year. The festival's Australian co-founder, Danny Rogers, aims to keep it small and manageable, unlike larger festivals that struggle with competition and poor ticket sales. Laneway's programming focuses on spotting indie music's next big thing, with a balanced lineup of acts. The festival has seen significant growth in Singapore, with 4,000 tickets sold for 2014's show, and is expected to reach 10,000-12,000 attendees next year.

site_title: Emirates demands on 777X specs precede record order
summary: Emirates president Tim Clark is pushing Boeing to finalize specifications for the 777X before placing a record-breaking order. The airline is demanding extra thrust for hot climates and is scrutinizing engine performance. Clark expects Boeing to deliver a deal at the upcoming Dubai Air Show, despite saying the manufacturer still has "work to do." Emirates is also considering alternatives, such as the Airbus A350-1000, which is set to enter service before the 777X.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: F&N bondholders are concerned the group may default rather than pay more to list its property business. Singapore and Taiwan have signed an economic partnership agreement eliminating import duties and taxes. China's top party members will meet to craft guidelines for the country's future economic path. DBS is offering to buy back preference shares. Keppel Corp landed a US$1.1 billion contract, while StarHub's Q3 profit dipped 1%. The government is investing $30 million in medical and clean-technology start-ups. Malaysia's property market is expected to slow down, and one-fifth of the world's biggest banks may be broken up.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q3 profit doubles to $16 million
summary: Roxy-Pacific's Q3 profit doubled to $16.1 million, driven by a 76% revenue increase to $76.7 million, primarily from its property development business, which more than doubled to $64.1 million. Hotel revenue declined 7% to $12.2 million due to the competitive Singapore hotel market.

site_title: LSEG picked for post-trade system
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has chosen London Stock Exchange Group's (LSEG) MillenniumIT as its new post-trade system provider. The system, expected to begin operating in phases from 2015, aims to shorten time-to-market, increase efficiency, and enrich services for members and retail investors. The new system will support SGX's growth strategy and enable additional post-trade services regionally.

site_title: India relaxes rules on foreign bank ownership
summary: India's central bank has relaxed rules on foreign bank ownership, allowing foreign banks to open retail branches through subsidiaries incorporated in the country. The new regulations require foreign banks to invest a minimum of 5 billion rupees in equity capital, have separate boards with at least half Indian directors, and abide by guidelines. The move aims to increase competition and efficiency in the local banking sector, but has drawn criticism from opposition parties. The rules apply to banks from countries that reciprocate by letting in Indian banks, with US banks eligible to compete on a nearly equal footing with domestic banks.

site_title: Visceral merry-go-round
summary: A play called "Gruesome Playground Injuries" by Rajiv Joseph tells the twisted love story of Doug and Kayleen over the course of eight scenes at five-year intervals. The play follows the pair as they endure various accidents, ailments, and angst, tracing their lives from elementary school to adulthood. With a non-linear narrative and a focus on the self-inflicted nature of their wounds, the play explores the destructive power of love. The production features Alan Wong and Seong Hui Xuan, and is currently playing at the Esplanade Theatre Studio.

site_title: China plenum expected to launch big reform agenda
summary: China's top party members will convene for a four-day meeting in Beijing, crafting guidelines for the country's future economic path. The agenda is expected to focus on fiscal issues, including interest rates and yuan convertibility. President Xi Jinping has called for a "profound revolution" in the economy, which could involve dismantling state-owned enterprises, reforming land rights, and granting a social security net. Analysts warn that vested interests among SOEs, local governments, and party members may slow reform momentum, while finding a consensus between party factions and a balanced pace of reform are also key challenges.

site_title: Ramping up art initiatives
summary: The Centre for Contemporary Art (CCA) at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore aims to bridge the gap between research and artistic production. Founded by Professor Ute Meta Bauer, the CCA will host exhibitions, residencies, and research programs, focusing on cross-disciplinary exchanges and addressing topics such as globalization, urbanization, and social change. The center seeks to establish Singapore as a hub for the arts in Southeast Asia and foster a culture of research in the field.

site_title: Swissco posts 85.2% jump in Q3 profit
summary: Swissco Holdings reported a 85.2% increase in Q3 net profit to $6.4 million, driven by expected improvements in its maritime services segment. Revenue fell 45.4% to $13.8 million, mainly due to lower maritime services contribution. Earnings per share rose sharply to 1.473 cents. The company expects increased demand for offshore support vessels due to the oil and gas industry's heightened interest.

site_title: Lost boys and girls
summary: A secret art exhibition, "The End of History," is showcasing the dark and macabre paintings of Singapore artist Huang Wei and Alan Oei. The exhibition features paintings of children with injuries, hinting at the suffering they endured during war. The event, held in a secret shophouse location, requires visitors to spend about an hour viewing the artworks, accompanied by actors and a key to unlock an object on site. Tickets are available for $25, and prices for the paintings range from $3,200 to $12,800.

site_title: Boutique boom
summary: Singapore is attracting global fashion brands with its high-end shopping scene, with over five new boutiques opening this month, including COS, Roger Vivier, Valextra, Kate Spade Saturday, and Tom Ford. Established European and US brands are expanding into the market, drawn by Singapore's brand-aware consumers, many of whom are frequent travelers or online shoppers. The influx of new boutiques is expected to boost retail therapy for shoppers ahead of the Christmas season.

site_title: Microdevelopers offer new lease of life
summary: Microdevelopers Bernice Radle and Jason Wilson, both 27, are revitalizing Buffalo's real estate market by purchasing derelict properties on a small scale and rehabbing them to rent. At the city's annual auction, they bought over 4,300 parcels of vacant lots and houses, with total purchases exceeding $71,000. This is their second auction, with their first yielding a vacant lot and three century-old houses. By taking on debt and rehabilitating properties, Radle and Wilson aim to revitalize the area and provide affordable housing options.

site_title: Yoma in the black with Q2 net profit of $3.3m
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a net profit of $3.3 million for its Q2 fiscal period, surpassing the net loss of $4.2 million in the same period last year. Revenue more than doubled to $27 million, driven by strong sales of residences and land development rights. The company's real estate division contributed significantly to the revenue surge, with sales of land development rights for two buildings in Star City generating $15.1 million. Earnings per share were 0.29 cents, up from a loss of 0.44 cents last year.

site_title: Preserving the fine art of Chinese ink painting
summary: Chinese artist Nan Qi showcases his passion for preserving Chinese ink painting through his solo exhibition "Authority Sex Money" at the Art Plural Gallery in Singapore. The exhibition features 30 works created between 2006 and 2013, with prices ranging from $6,000 to $120,000. Nan Qi, a founding director of the Chinese Painting Association, believes that the "charm and spirit" of Chinese ink painting is worth preserving, despite its association with the former Chinese leader Mao Zedong. The artist hopes that the growing Chinese economy will increase international appreciation for contemporary Chinese ink art.

site_title: Hyflux reports 74% jump in Q3 earnings
summary: Hyflux reported a 74% increase in Q3 net income to $25.3 million, driven by a 26% rise in revenue to $187.7 million. Earnings per share rose to 2.33 cents from 1.01 cents last year. The company attributed the growth to the municipal sector, which accounted for 95% of revenue. Hyflux also provided updates on its Tuaspring Desalination Plant and Dahej desalination project, with the latter expected to begin EPC activities next year.

site_title: Wilmar turns in higher Q3 gain of US$416m
summary: Wilmar International reported a higher net profit of US$416 million for the third quarter, driven by strong sales growth and improved margins in most business segments. However, revenue fell 4.2% due to significantly lower palm oil prices. The company's consumer products and sugar segments posted higher profits, while oilseeds and grains showed strong crush margins. Wilmar's cash and cash equivalents increased by US$857.3 million to US$2.4 billion, and the company did not declare a dividend for the quarter.

site_title: When poetry melds with calligraphy
summary: Art curator Iola Liu is showcasing the works of Chinese ink artist Fan Chang Tien, who taught and mentored a generation of artists in Singapore. Fan, a contemporary of notable artists, rarely sold his paintings commercially and instead donated them to charity. His works will be featured in a solo exhibition at Asia Art Collective from November 9-30, featuring over 20 pieces from his students. The exhibition highlights Fan's unique blend of poetry and calligraphy with painting, a talent now rare in the art world.

site_title: Around Town
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

UK comedian Michael McIntyre is set to perform at The Star Theatre on Nov 12, with ticket prices ranging from $108 to $168. American rock band Matchbox Twenty will perform at the Singapore Indoor Stadium on Nov 10, with ticket prices from $68 to $108. The Singapore Writers Festival features a staged reading of Gao Xing Jian's play Nocturnal Wanderer at The Arts House. Art exhibition Lokanat - Ground Zero X is on display at the Gajah Gallery until Nov 24, with admission free. Super 0 Season 2 kicks off at The Annex@The Mill, and Nutopia offers a Roald Dahl-themed dinner series.

site_title: Thakral Corp sinks to Q3 loss in absence of one-off gains
summary: Thakral Corp reported a Q3 net loss of $1.08 million, down from a $12.8 million profit a year ago, due to the absence of one-off gains. Revenue rose 44% to $107.7 million, primarily driven by improved channel sales. The company posted a 28% increase in 9-month revenue to $288.4 million, but remains cautious about its outlook due to weak demand in China. Thakral will explore new brands and product lines to boost profitability.

site_title: Rabobank inks lease at South Beach Tower
summary: Rabobank has signed a lease for approximately 26,000 sq ft at the South Beach Tower in Singapore, marking the building's first deal. Meanwhile, Booking.com has inked a lease for 45,000 sq ft at Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 3. The Singapore office market is experiencing strong leasing activity, with demand driven by smaller financial institutions and businesses. Vacancies are falling in older CBD office buildings, leading to rent increases, with landlords pushing up rents for smaller areas.

site_title: SMRT revamps pay and career path for bus drivers
summary: SMRT Corporation, a Singaporean public transport operator, has introduced a new pay and career path scheme for its bus drivers, offering an average monthly salary of up to $3,500 with overtime and performance incentives. The new framework includes career progression opportunities for drivers to become supervisory positions with instructor responsibilities. Analysts remain bearish on SMRT due to higher costs and difficulties in attracting local drivers, while rival SBS Transit is also seen to be competitive in offering similar pay to its drivers.

site_title: SIA Engg Q2 profit climbs 5.8% as revenue inches up
summary: SIA Engineering Company reported a 5.8% increase in net profit to $71 million for the second quarter, driven by a 3.3% rise in revenue. Earnings per share rose to 6.39 cents. The group's six-month net profit was $140 million, with operating profit at $56.2 million. A dividend of seven cents per share was recommended, payable on November 28. Despite a slight drop in revenue, the company expects stable performance and growth opportunities, citing its diversified services and strong balance sheet.

site_title: FJ Benjamin Q1 profit plunges 83%
summary: FJ Benjamin Holdings' Q1 net profit plummeted 83% to $396,000, driven by a fair value loss on investment securities and forex losses. Sales rose 2% to $96 million, with South-east Asian markets showing growth, while North Asian markets declined due to a slowdown in luxury timepiece sales. The company attributed losses to a slowdown in demand and reduced tourist spending. Despite the earnings decline, FJ Benjamin plans to invest in new brands and expand its retail footprint, with new store openings scheduled in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Vard earnings plunge 66.7% in Q3
summary: Vard Holdings reported a 66.7% drop in Q3 net profit to 76 million Norwegian kroner due to an overload situation at its Brazilian yard, resulting in delays and cost overruns. Revenue decreased 3.5% to 2.37 billion kroner, while earnings per share fell to 0.06 krone. The company delivered four vessels and secured contracts for six newbuildings, but operating profit declined to 72 million kroner. Despite stable operations at European shipyards, the group expects continued growth in oil companies' E&P spending in 2014, driving demand for its products.

site_title: BAE to close Portsmouth yard, cut shipbuilding jobs
summary: BAE Systems will close its Portsmouth yard, resulting in the loss of 940 jobs, and cut 835 shipbuilding positions in Filton, Glasgow, and Rosyth by 2016. The company will retain an engineering team in Portsmouth to support the construction of three new offshore patrol vessels for the Royal Navy. The restructuring will be funded by the Ministry of Defence, with the UK's global workforce reduced by 1.3% to 88,200 people. The government also announced plans for the new vessels, which will play a key role in counterterrorism and anti-smuggling operations.

site_title: Tuck Yew to respond on fare recommendations on Monday
summary: Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew has expressed encouragement over public support for fare recommendations by the Fare Review Mechanism Committee, particularly those on fare concessions. The committee's report proposed enhancing existing concession schemes, introducing new schemes for low-income workers and people with disabilities, and a fare formula that includes energy costs. Lui will address questions on the report's recommendations during the November parliamentary sitting. The proposed concessions could add about 500,000 new beneficiaries to the current 1.2 million commuters receiving public transport concessions, with fare increases expected to be offset by PTO contributions to the Public Transport Fund.

site_title: F&N spat with Myanmar partner turning ugly
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) is embroiled in a dispute with Myanmar Economic Holdings Limited (MEHL) over the ownership of Myanmar Brewery, with MEHL claiming a "clear right" to buy out F&N's 55% stake valued at US$246 million. F&N disputes the claim, stating that MEHL is undervaluing the asset and has no basis for the arbitration proceedings. The dispute is the first major issue between a foreign investor and a Myanmar state-owned enterprise since the country's reform.

images.alt_text: An ugly spat is unfolding between Fraser and Neave (F&N) and a Myanmar state-owned enterprise - at a time when Singapore companies are flocking to the emerging market that is just about to leave its pariah status behind for good - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: UK-Russia device may make Arctic route safer
summary: The UK and Russia are developing a radio navigation system to improve safety on the Arctic shipping route. The eLoran system, being tested in the UK, could be linked with Russia's eChayka system, providing alternative position and timing signals for navigation. This comes as the Arctic route faces risks from extreme weather and icebergs, with vessels increasingly relying on satellite signals that can be vulnerable to signal loss or interference. The system could help reduce journey times and enhance shipping safety, with Russia aiming to expand its clout through the Arctic.

site_title: Province in Canada issues yuan bonds
summary: British Columbia, Canada, has become the first foreign government to issue a yuan-denominated offshore bond, with 2.5 billion yuan set to yield 2.25%. The move is seen as a potential precursor to more foreign governments and entities issuing yuan-denominated bonds, particularly with the upcoming Third Plenary of the Chinese Communist Party in Beijing. Former Goldman Sachs vice-president Kenneth Courtis predicts more non-Chinese governments and companies will follow suit, citing Canada's Alberta province as a likely next issuer.

site_title: Stamford Land sees strong sales for Aussie housing project
summary: Stamford Land Corporation announced record sales of A$250 million for its mixed-use residential project, Macquarie Park Village, outside Sydney, despite a 1.2% dip in net profit to $9.3 million for the six months to September. The project, which includes 650 apartments and commercial offices, was sold out in its initial stage. The company's overall revenue rose 6.4% to $133 million, driven by increased expenses from development property sales.

site_title: British home prices climb at fastest pace since 2010: Survey
summary: British house prices rose by 6.9% annually in October, the fastest pace since May 2010, according to a Halifax survey. This follows a 6.2% increase in September. The average home price is now £171,991. Demand has increased due to government-backed schemes, low interest rates, and higher consumer confidence. However, prices remain below pre-2006/2007 levels, and concerns over the pace of price increases persist.

site_title: StarHub's Q3 earnings dip despite fall in costs
summary: StarHub's Q3 net profit dropped 1% to $95.3 million, despite a 1.2% decrease in expenses. Operating revenue fell 1.2% to $578.8 million due to lower equipment sales. The company lowered its full-year operating revenue forecast, expecting it to be lower than 2012's. However, Ebitda margin is expected to be around 32%, up from 31%. The telco saw growth in mobile revenue and fixed network services, with a net increase in pay-TV subscribers for the first time in six quarters.

site_title: Trove of tastes in ageing wine
summary: A 1978 Nuits St Georges 1er cru Les Vaucrains from Domaine Henri Gouges and a 1988 Corton-Charlemagne from Domaine Joseph Faiveley have been savored, showcasing the benefits of long-term wine storage. The Nuits St Georges, with its complex Pinot Noir flavor, required 40 years to mature, while the Corton-Charlemagne, from the era of Erwan Faiveley, reached its peak at 25 years. These exceptional wines highlight the importance of patience and proper storage to unlock their full potential, and their rarity makes them challenging to find.

site_title: Vanke to build condos for China's rich in Singapore
summary: China Vanke Co, the country's largest mainland-listed property developer, is building apartments in Singapore for wealthy Chinese buyers amid curbs on luxury residences at home. The company sold $140 million of four-year notes with a 3.275% coupon, a premium on average Chinese bonds. This move is part of a larger trend by mainland builders to raise debt in foreign currencies, driven by a desire for funding and diversification.

site_title: Peranakan recipes unlocked from a private kitchen
summary: Rosaline Soon, a 73-year-old Singaporean, has published three cookbooks featuring her family's Peranakan recipes, which she learned through self-study after opening her restaurant, Ming's Cafe & Pub, 20 years ago. Despite not growing up with a family cook, Soon's dedication to the craft is evident in her labors of love. The cookbooks showcase her commitment to preserving and sharing her family's culinary heritage, which dates back generations.

site_title: PLife Reit's Q3 DPU rises to 2.66 cents
summary: Parksay Life Real Estate Investment Trust (PLife Reit) reported a 3.5% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.66 cents for the third quarter, driven by a 3.5% increase in distributable income to $16.1 million. Gross revenue dipped 2.4% to $23.3 million, but net property income also fell 2.4% to $21.8 million. The Reit maintains a neutral outlook on medium-term acquisition prospects, citing stabilizing global markets and a robust long-term prospects for the regional healthcare industry.

site_title: Landlords hog centre stage
summary: A new Mandarin play, Citizen Pig, tells the stories of the worst landlords experienced by theatre directors Liu Xiaoyi and Oliver Chong. The play features true stories of landlords who have engaged in illegal activities, such as overpacking apartments and renting out non-existent spaces. Liu Xiaoyi, who has lived in 10 different HDB flats in Singapore over the past 10 years, aims to shed light on the often-overlooked stories of landlords and tenants, highlighting the struggles faced by tenants due to high rents and expensive land.

site_title: Keppel beats pack to land US$1.1b job
summary: Keppel Corp secured a US$1.1 billion contract to build five KFELS Super B class jack-up rigs for Transocean Ltd, beating competition from seven international shipyards. Keppel's ability to meet a tight delivery schedule and its execution track record led to the win. The first rig will be delivered in Q1 2016, with subsequent ones delivered at four-month intervals until Q3 2017. This contract reinforces Singapore shipyards as the preferred offshore rig builders for established drillers.

site_title: CEOs spell out reasons for support to the cause
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association (SIAS) is holding the 4th Singapore Corporate Governance Week (CG Week) from Nov 8 to 15. Over 102 companies, including CEOs from leading firms such as Courts Asia, Hiap Hoe, C&G Environmental Protection Holdings, and Nam Cheong, have signed a Statement of Support for good corporate governance standards. The statement emphasizes the importance of transparency and accountability in enhancing shareholder value and promoting a healthy investment environment. The CEOs expressed their commitment to upholding high standards of corporate governance, citing its benefits to stakeholders and the economy.

site_title: In the cross-hairs of rival samurais
summary: Japanese playwright Hisashi Inoue wrote a script for "Musashi" in 2010, envisioning actors Tatsuya Fujiwara and Kaiji Ito and director Yukio Ninagawa to stage it. The play, based on a famous samurai tale, premiered in Japan and later toured major cities, including London and New York. Inoue aimed to convey a message about stopping the cycle of revenge, and Ninagawa staged the play to immerse audiences in the world of samurais. Tickets for the final two shows in Singapore have sold out.

site_title: Lion Air eyeing deal for 50 Bombardiers
summary: Lion Air, Indonesia's parent company, aims to purchase at least 50 Bombardier CS300 aircraft for over $3 billion, with deliveries expected to start in 2016. The deal, if successful, would be the latest in Lion Group's massive aviation investments, following $46 billion plane orders from Airbus and Boeing. However, concerns about safety and pilot training have been raised due to Lion Air's rapid expansion, following a fatal accident in April.

site_title: Shops at The Interlace up for sale
summary: The eight strata-titled shops at The Interlace condominium in Singapore have been put up for sale with a guide price of over $2,500 per square foot. The shops range from 388 to 1,119 square feet and can be sold individually or as a group. The sale will be done by expression of interest, with a minimum offer of $970,000 for the smallest unit or $13.35 million for all eight units. This follows strong demand for strata-titled shops in the past six months, with prices ranging from $2,000 to $4,500 per square foot.

site_title: CRCT buys Grand Canyon Mall from CMA for 1.8b yuan
summary: CRCT buys Grand Canyon Mall from CMA for 1.82 billion yuan (S$368 million), fulfilling two conditions including government approval and financing. The mall, in Beijing, has an average monthly footfall of over 1 million and is valued at 26,000 yuan per square meter. CRCT will partly finance the acquisition through an equity fund-raising and external borrowing, with the targeted completion date now set for the end of this year.

site_title: More open, timely news releases needed: study
summary: A study of 700 listed companies in Singapore found that most firms prefer online platforms for stakeholder engagement, but still struggle with timely and clear communication. Only 14% notify the market ahead of time when releasing earnings results, and 21% issue profit warnings. CFOs are urged to help stakeholders discern facts from noise and provide clear guidance for investors. Traditional methods, such as face-to-face engagements, can also play a crucial role in effective communication.

site_title: Prices dive in Greek housing market
summary: Greece's housing market has plummeted, with residential property prices dropping by nearly a third in six years due to the country's recession and EU-IMF bailout policies. Experts blame government taxation on property owners, which has worsened the situation. Building activity has declined by 44% and 185,000 jobs have been lost in the construction sector. The government has attempted to revive the sector by offering residence permits to non-EU investors, but the sector remains moribund, with 75% of mortgage payments in arrears and 250,000 new buildings awaiting buyers.

site_title: Top management changes at SATS
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based groundhandler, announced changes to its senior management roles effective January 1, 2014. Tan Chuan Lye, current president and CEO, will step down as CEO and become chairman of food solutions. Yacoob Piperdi will assume executive VP of gateway services, while Wong Hong will take over as executive VP of food solutions. Alexander Hungate, former HSBC executive, will become president and CEO. Shares in SATS closed four cents lower at $3.36 following the announcement.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Tiong Woon, a tugboat and barge operator, reported an 11% increase in Q1 profit to $4.6 million, driven by the sale of a loss-making business. Ellipsiz, a semiconductor equipment supplier, posted a $6.3 million net profit, largely due to a one-time negative goodwill charge. Aspial Corp, a diversified jeweler, saw a 24% rise in Q3 profit to $18 million, driven by property development sales. ST Aerospace's subsidiary, WingStar, is forming a 50-50 joint venture to acquire aircraft for lease or conversion.

site_title: Priciest London luxury homes lose their shine
summary: London's most expensive homes, valued at over £15 million, have seen little to no price gain this year due to concerns over tax increases and high asking prices. The market has stalled, with prices rising only 5% for properties between £1.8 million and £5 million. Luxury residences outside central London rose by about 10%, while central London's top-tier market is expected to increase by 23.1% by 2018. Tax worries and a lack of supply are cited as factors deterring wealthy buyers.

site_title: EU set to fine banks in rigging probe
summary: EU antitrust regulators are set to fine six global banks, including Deutsche Bank, JPMorgan, and HSBC, for suspected rigging of benchmark eurozone interest rates. The penalties, expected to be around 10% of the banks' global revenue, are the first punishment meted out by Brussels in a global probe. The fines are related to alleged manipulation of Euribor and Libor, with some banks agreeing to settle in exchange for a 10% reduction. The EU can impose fines of up to 10% of a company's global revenue for breaches of antitrust rules.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC Q3 net up at US$13.3m
summary: STATS ChipPAC reported a third-quarter net profit of US$13.3 million, up from US$3.2 million in the year-ago quarter. Net revenue declined to US$400.8 million, down from US$408.3 million a year earlier. The company attributed the decline to business disruption caused by floods in Thailand and costs associated with the planned closure of its Malaysia plant. Adjusted Ebitda was US$112.1 million, down from US$121.9 million in the year-ago quarter. The company expects fourth-quarter revenues to be flat to 5% decrease and adjusted Ebitda in the range of 21-25% of revenue.

site_title: Linking leases to productivity not practical
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that achieving the goal of sustained 2-3% annual productivity growth over a decade remains challenging. The government is working on systemic improvements in industries such as construction, logistics, and retail to boost productivity. To support this, the government plans to implement a productivity test for JTC tenants seeking to renew their leases, requiring them to submit proposals on how to raise efficiency levels and set milestones. This move aims to push SMEs to upgrade their efficiency, potentially leading to relocation or commercial landlord changes if they fail to meet the standards.

site_title: Jardine C&C hits Q3 bump amid Astra's challenges
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (C&C) reported a 31% decline in net profit to US$222 million in Q3 amid stiff competition and high labor costs. The decline was partly due to challenges faced by its majority-stakeholder PT Astra International, which reported an 8% decrease in net profit. Higher labor costs, increased competition in the car market, and lower commodity prices also impacted earnings. Underlying net profit declined 18% to US$218 million. Shares of Jardine C&C gained 0.25% to close at S$36.77.

site_title: SembMarine - All under one roof in 10 years
summary: SembCorp Marine (SembMarine) has completed the first phase of its integrated shipyard, with the goal of housing its five dispersed shipyards under one roof by 2024. The project aims to integrate modernizing, upgrading, and re-scaling its existing facilities to meet intense competition from Korean and Chinese yards. The integrated shipyard will accommodate all of SembMarine's Singapore yards, including the two largest and oldest ones, and will free up older sites for potential redevelopment. The project is driven by three key factors: economies, increased dock capacity, and redevelopment of waterfront land.

site_title: Italy to limit large cruise ship traffic in Venice
summary: Italy plans to limit large cruise ship traffic in the Venice lagoon, banning vessels over 96,000 gross tonnes from November 2014. The move follows growing concerns about the damage caused by increasing cruise ship traffic to the fragile city. Prime Minister Enrico Letta approved plans to restrict or shut down cruise ship traffic in parts of the lagoon and near Saint Mark's Square. The decision aims to protect the city's delicate environment and reduce pollution.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: F&N, a Singaporean brewery, is being sued by Myanmar Economic Holdings of Myanmar over a joint-venture brewery. The arbitration proceedings were initiated due to disagreements between the two companies. The dispute is part of a larger spat between F&N and its partner, Myanmar Economic Holdings of Myanmar. The exact details of the dispute are not specified in the article.

site_title: Closing gap on air travel shopping
summary: The International Air Transport Association (Iata) is working to bridge the gap between airline websites and travel agents by implementing the New Distribution Capability (NDC) standard, which will enable airlines to display and sell their full range of products through travel agents and websites. The goal is to provide greater transparency and customization for consumers, with nearly half of travelers interested in sharing personal preferences to receive tailored offers. The initiative aims to create a more efficient and competitive industry, with a global rollout expected to begin in 2016.

site_title: Baker Tech Q3 net down 37%
summary: Baker Technology reported a 37% decline in Q3 net profit to $3.6 million, down from $5.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 5% to $20.7 million, while gross profit dropped 18% to $6.7 million. The company's 9-month net profit slid 77% to $18.2 million. Despite a higher net order book of $55 million, the counter closed half a cent lower at 26 cents.

site_title: MAS: Conditions ripe for S'pore to become global insurance hub
summary: Singapore aims to become a global insurance hub by 2020, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) working with existing players to build up capabilities. The country is already recognized as Asia's leading reinsurance hub, with 16 of the world's top 25 reinsurers having regional hubs here. MAS plans to expand specialty insurance and reinsurance underwriting and broking capabilities, and promote growth in emerging business lines such as cyber risks. The goal is to accept global risks by 2020, with the industry expected to grow at 8% a year in Asia over the next decade.

site_title: The blowtorch that was felt around the island
summary: A fire at SingTel's Bukit Panjang exchange in Singapore was caused by an employee using an unauthorised blowtorch for maintenance work on a pipe, damaging 149 fibre optic cables and disrupting services for tens of thousands of customers. The employee has been suspended pending an independent review by the SingTel board committee of inquiry. The telco has taken steps to prevent a repeat, including limiting heat-based maintenance, introducing better tools and equipment, and reinforcing training on safety requirements. SingTel's CEO apologised to customers for the inconvenience caused and welcomed recommendations from the inquiry to enhance operations.

site_title: New wave of renewable energy - NTU-Sentosa's tidal turbine project
summary: Singapore has launched its first tidal turbine project at the Sentosa Boardwalk, a collaboration between NTU-Sentosa and the Nanyang Technological University. The project aims to harness low-flow tidal energy, a more reliable resource than wind and solar, which are susceptible to weather changes. If successful, tidal energy could become a sustainable resource, potentially meeting 10-20% of Singapore's energy needs. The project, funded by the Ministry of Trade and Industry, Sentosa Development, and NTU, is expected to prove commercially viable in 5-10 years, with plans to deploy larger turbines near the Southern Islands and Pulau Semakau.

site_title: US Navy vows to cut cost of building new aircraft carriers
summary: The US Navy has pledged to cut the cost of building new aircraft carriers, with the USS Gerald R Ford expected to cost $12.9 billion, 25% more than forecast. Rear Admiral Thomas Moore, in charge of aircraft carriers, aims to reduce costs for the next carrier, the USS John F Kennedy, by $1.2 billion. The Navy is working with Huntington Ingalls Industries and the US Congress to implement cost controls and meet the $11.4 billion cost cap imposed by Congress. The goal is to maintain a fleet of 11 aircraft carriers while addressing budget constraints.

site_title: Jason Marine posts $1.1m H1 profit
summary: Jason Marine Group reported a net profit of $1.1 million for the first six months of FY2014, up from a loss of $1.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue grew 57% to $22.6 million, driven by increased sales across all three business segments. Gross margin improved by 3.2 percentage points to 26.9%. The company generated $1.4 million in net cash from operating activities and has a net cash balance of $14.2 million. Despite challenging conditions, the group remains cautious but is well-positioned to grow prudently.

site_title: Average billionaire here is a 64-year-old male
summary: The inaugural Wealth-X and UBS Billionaire Census 2013 reveals that the average billionaire in Singapore is 64 years old, male, and has likely built his wealth from finance, banking, and investments. Asia saw the highest percentage rise in billionaire population (3.7%) and strongest surge in wealth (13%), with 2,170 billionaires globally, a 5.3% increase in combined wealth to $6.5 trillion. By 2020, the billionaire population is expected to exceed 3,800, with China having the second-largest population, followed by the US.

site_title: SembMarine opens integrated yard at Tuas
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong opened Sembcorp Marine's new integrated yard in Tuas, aiming to consolidate the group's shipyards into a single facility by 2024, boosting productivity. The yard will feature a one-stop solutions hub for ship repair and conversion, shipbuilding, and offshore engineering, leveraging modern technologies to double output. The government will support the offshore and marine industry with four-pronged approaches, including training, research, talent development, and eco-system building, to enhance capabilities and competitiveness.

site_title: FAA tightens pilot training requirements
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has imposed stricter training requirements for commercial airline pilots, nearly four years after the Colgan Air 3407 crash killed 50 people in upstate New York. The new rules require additional training on preventing and reacting to aircraft stalls, better tracking of pilot training and performance, and handling planes in crosswinds and gusty conditions. The changes aim to raise the bar on safety, following rule changes that mandated minimum sleep and time off between flights. The FAA administrator says the updated training will give pilots the most advanced training available to handle emergency events.

site_title: Jakarta may open up ports, airports to foreign investors
summary: Indonesian officials propose to open up ports, airports, and other industries to foreign investors, including operating airports through public-private partnerships. The government plans to amend its "negative investment list" to allow higher foreign ownership in sectors such as pharmaceuticals, telecommunications, and tourism, with ceiling increases ranging from 45% to 85%. The proposals need President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono's approval, with some industries, like alcohol, left unchanged.

site_title: Pacific Radiance heading for mainboard listing
summary: Pacific Radiance, a Singapore-based offshore marine group, is set to list on the Singapore Exchange mainboard to raise capital for expansion. The company priced its $154.7 million IPO at 90 cents per share, valuing it at $653.2 million. Pacific Radiance plans to expand its fleet to capitalize on growing oil and gas business activity in the region, with a focus on South-east Asia, particularly Malaysia and Indonesia. The company aims to increase its capacity and capture strategic initiatives through mergers and acquisitions, with a growth strategy spanning over a decade.

site_title: Collective sale effort rolls again for Tanglin Shopping Centre
summary: Tanglin Shopping Centre, a 68,512 sq ft freehold site in Singapore, is back on the en bloc market after several failed attempts. Millennium & Copthorne Hotels plc (M&C) has signed a collective sale agreement for its 34% interest in the property through a subsidiary. An independent sales committee has been authorized to market the property, with at least 80% of owners required to agree to a collective sale. The site has been put up for sale multiple times in recent years, with a reported reserve price of $1.25 billion.

site_title: NZ govt reviewing import duties on home building materials
summary: The New Zealand government is reviewing import duties on home building materials to help reduce soaring house prices. The current tariffs on building materials are too high, making them 30% more expensive than in Australia. The government aims to increase competition and transparency to bring down costs. An options paper outlines possible measures, including adjusting tariffs and imposing anti-dumping duties. Submissions on the paper will close on December 18. The move is expected to help kiwi families access more fairly priced building materials and homes.

site_title: Bubble fears as Aussie home prices soar
summary: Australia's housing market is experiencing rapid price gains, driven by low mortgage rates and constrained supply. The median home price in Sydney surged 13% to a record A$718,122, while the national average price rose 7.4% to A$605,336. Investors, including self-managed superannuation funds and foreign buyers, are fueling the market, raising concerns of a housing bubble. Experts warn that if economic conditions worsen, investors may "dump their properties," putting downward pressure on prices. The Australian government is keen to see house prices rise to boost the construction industry and ease a housing shortage.

site_title: Vantage takes top spot from Pimco in mutual fund ranking
summary: Bill Gross' Pimco Total Return Fund has lost $37.5 billion in assets since the start of 2013, ending October with $247.9 billion, as investors shift to stock funds amid concerns of tapering US Federal Reserve bond-buying. Vanguard's Total Stock Market Index Fund took the top spot with $251 billion in assets, marking the fifth year of the bull market in US equities. Investors are pulling from traditional fixed-income funds to low-cost index funds, driven by concerns of ending bond rally and rising interest rates.

site_title: EU proposes to keep jet fuel imports duty-free
summary: The European Commission has proposed to keep jet fuel imports duty-free for the EU, effectively scrapping a planned 4.7% tariff that was set to take effect on January 1. This decision was met with relief from the aviation sector, fuel traders, and oil producers in the Middle East and India, who had feared the tariff could impact their business. The proposal is expected to be endorsed by EU member states, maintaining the current duty-free status of jet fuel imports.

site_title: Ferry owners' fears
summary: The ferry industry is urging governments to prioritize safety measures that go beyond design, citing the importance of the human factor in accidents. Following the sinking of the Philippine ferry St Thomas Aquinas, which killed over 100 people, the industry is pushing for a more holistic approach to safety, focusing on crew training and operational measures. Experts warn that the industry's reliance on technical aids may not be enough to prevent accidents, and that upgrading or replacing aging ships is crucial to improving safety.

site_title: Mencast Q3 net up 44%
summary: Mencast Holdings Ltd reported a 44% year-on-year increase in Q3 net profit to $1.59 million, driven by an 18% rise in turnover to $25.6 million. The company's offshore and engineering segment became its largest revenue contributor, with a 45% increase from last year. For the nine-month period, net profit rose 15% to $9.25 million, with turnover increasing 26% to $71.24 million.

site_title: New consolidation accounting rule may pose some challenges for companies
summary: A new consolidation accounting rule, FRS 110, is set to take effect on January 1, 2014, and may pose challenges for companies due to its increased complexity and judgment required to apply it. The rule redefines entities to be consolidated, potentially incurring additional costs for companies like United Overseas Bank (UOB), which recently wound up its associate, United International Securities (UIS). Experts warn that certain types of companies, such as those with special-purpose entities or fund/asset managers, may face significant challenges in adopting the standard.

site_title: COE premiums fall across the board again
summary: COE premiums in Singapore fell across the board for the second consecutive tender, with Category A and Cat B certificates decreasing by $4,280 and $3,332, respectively. Cat C, for goods vehicles, plummeted 18.4% to a seven-month low of $55,503, largely due to dealers clearing existing stocks ahead of the 2014 emission standard. The passenger car market is also experiencing weak demand, attributed to loan curbs and higher registration taxes, affecting luxury sector sales.

site_title: October securities trading slows on penny stock saga
summary: Singapore Exchange's securities trading slowed in October due to the penny stock saga and Federal Reserve's non-taper decision, with total value traded falling 6% year-over-year to $24.7 billion. However, derivatives trading and clearing activities grew, with open interest reaching a record high. Analysts attribute the growth to increased market interest and a more optimistic environment for derivatives business, particularly equity index futures. Despite the slowdown, analysts expect securities trading to pick up in January.

site_title: BreadTalk Q3 profit flat
summary: BreadTalk reported a flat net profit of $3.39 million in its third quarter, despite a 22.2% rise in revenue to $142.6 million. Earnings per share remained unchanged at 1.21 cents. The group attributed the flat profit to higher distribution and selling expenses, administrative expenses, and a provision for tax. Its food atrium division was the standout performer, with revenue increasing 28.9% and net profit more than eight times in the nine months.

site_title: Boeing in talks to make its new jet near Seattle
summary: Boeing is in advanced talks with the machinists' union to assemble the 777X jet and build its wings in the Seattle area, with final assembly likely to occur at the company's Everett plant. The deal, which could include a multi-year contract extension and bonuses, aims to keep the work local and control costs. Industry sources indicate that Boeing wants to lock in a labour deal before launching the 777X at the Dubai Airshow in November, with the decision having long-term implications for the aerospace industry.

site_title: Africa spells opportunities for Singapore Inc
summary: Africa is poised to become a major investment opportunity for Singapore Inc, with the World Bank projecting 5.6% economic growth this year. The continent boasts high rates of urbanization, growth in discretionary incomes, and infrastructure spending, making it an attractive destination for investors. Despite mixed governance quality, major improvements have been made in several countries, and security concerns have decreased. Singapore's commercial engagement with Africa is below potential, with only 55 Singapore companies operating on the continent, compared to hundreds in Asia.

site_title: OUEHT DPU at 1.24 cents, above forecast
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust announced its maiden distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.24 cents, exceeding its forecast of 1.21 cents, driven by higher revenue from Mandarin Orchard and Mandarin Gallery. Distributable income reached $16.3 million, a 2.7% increase from the forecast.

site_title: Temasek appoints Wing Tai head as deputy chairman
summary: Temasek Holdings has appointed Wing Tai Holdings chief Cheng Wai Keung as its deputy chairman, effective immediately. This appointment follows Temasek's new chairman Lim Boon Heng's takeover in February. Cheng, 63, has been a non-executive director and executive committee member since 2011. His new role underscores Temasek's commitment to diversifying its board with experienced industry professionals.

site_title: Falcon's Q2 net soars on one-off disposal income
summary: Falcon Energy posted a Q2 net profit of US$38.9 million, up from US$1.9 million a year earlier, driven by the disposal of two jack-up rigs that generated US$127.8 million in revenue. The firm's revenue rose to US$183.5 million, with its marine division increasing by 70% and oilfield services division seeing a 102% increase. Falcon Energy is optimistic about business prospects, citing buoyant demand and stable oil prices, and plans to invest in newer vessels to meet growing demand.

site_title: PCRT Q3 DPU down 2.1% at 0.95 cent
summary: PCRT, a China Retail Trust, reported a 2.1% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.95 cents for Q3, down from 0.97 cents in the same period last year. The amount available for distribution remained unchanged at $10.9 million. Operating performance at its Shenyang portfolio rose 20.3% to $1.8 million, driven by higher revenue from the Guangcai Group master-lease arrangement. Leasing at Shenyang Longemont Shopping Mall reached 85%, with total shopper traffic growing 183% year-over-year.

site_title: Fare review committee proposes more concessions
summary: The Fare Review Mechanism Committee (FRMC) has proposed more concessions and better monitoring of fare affordability in Singapore's public transport system. The report suggests schemes for the disabled and low-wage workers, as well as increased resources for the Public Transport Fund to benefit needy households.
