To ensure financial sustainability, the committee recommends a responsive fare formula, regular fare adjustments, and the rollover of fare adjustment quantum. The report's findings will be shared with the Ministry of Transport and the public, aiming to make public transport more accessible and affordable for all commuters.

site_title: Gold bug unfazed despite a slide in prices
summary: Fund manager Peter Schiff, a self-proclaimed "gold bug," remains optimistic about the future of gold, predicting it will reach a record US$2,000 per ounce within a year. Despite a 21% decline in gold's value this year, Schiff believes the US dollar will collapse and gold will surge due to inflation and government spending. His predictions have been met with skepticism, including from Austan Goolsbee, an economics professor, who argues that the Fed's money printing only offsets economic concerns.

site_title: October PMI points to stronger Q4 growth
summary: Singapore's October PMI rose to 51.2, signaling a stronger-than-expected pick-up in manufacturing activity, setting the economy on track for a better finish to the year. The reading was above the median estimate of 51, indicating expansion. The PMI also showed growth in new orders, new export orders, and higher output, with inventories continuing to contract. The stronger PMI reading is expected to boost the government's GDP growth forecast to 3.5-4%, but some economists caution that challenges remain, including volatile external demand dynamics and increased cost pressures.

site_title: Low-cost Indian mission to Mars blasts off
summary: India successfully launched its Mars Orbiter Mission, a low-cost rocket aimed at studying the Martian surface and atmosphere. The rocket, scheduled to orbit Mars by September, marks a significant achievement for the country's space program, which has developed rapidly despite economic challenges. This mission aims to position India as a budget player in the global space race, following in the footsteps of only the US, Europe, and Russia in sending probes to Mars. The success of the mission is seen as a boost to Indian national pride, particularly after a similar mission by China failed to leave Earth's orbit in 2011.

site_title: PSA set to make Yangtze Delta debut
summary: PSA International has formed a joint venture with Lianyungang Port Group to run Lianyungang Port in China's Yangtze River Delta, with the terminal expected to begin operations next year. The port has a designed capacity of 2.8 million 20-foot equivalent units and will support the container trade originating from Shandong and Jiangsu provinces. This marks PSA's first venture in the Yangtze River Delta region and its first collaboration with the Lianyungang Port Group.

site_title: J&J to pay US$2.2b in fines for improper marketing of drug
summary: Johnson & Johnson has agreed to pay $2.2 billion in fines for promoting the anti-psychotic drug Risperdal for unapproved uses, including to older adults, children, and people with developmental disabilities. This is the third-largest pharmaceutical settlement in US history and part of a decade-long effort to hold pharmaceutical companies accountable for illegal marketing practices. The settlement also resolves accusations of improper promotion for two other drugs, Natrecor and Invega. The company acknowledged promoting these drugs as a way to control patients with dementia and children with certain behavioral disabilities despite health risks.

site_title: Kuroda paints rosy picture of Japan's economy
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda presented a positive outlook on Japan's economy, stating that deflation is being overcome, economic growth is on track, and employment and wage trends are improving. Kuroda defended the BOJ's record in contributing to the country's economic improvement and reiterated that Abenomics is still on track. He noted that Japan's real GDP growth is projected at 2.7% in fiscal 2013, driven by domestic demand, and that wages are expected to rise as the labor market tightens.

site_title: A banner year for the US stock market
summary: The US stock market is expected to see its biggest annual increase since 1997, with the S&P 500 Index potentially reaching an all-time high. Strong year-end momentum, fueled by 82% of the time shares rising in the final two months of the year, is predicted to lift the index to a 20% gain. Investors are optimistic, with 80% of stocks in the index trading above their 50-day moving averages, and profit growth expected to pick up in the fourth quarter. Despite concerns over slowing earnings growth and the Federal Reserve's plan to curb stimulus, many believe the market's momentum will continue.

site_title: Terminal 4 a test bed for new concepts
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4, set to open in 2017, will test new concepts to increase efficiency and reduce staff, including self-service check-in and automated immigration clearance. The terminal aims to save 20% in security manpower. It will have a handling capacity of 16 million passengers annually and will be designed to prevent bottlenecks, with a focus on reducing labor needs. The terminal's design and technology will be evaluated to inform future development at Terminal 5, which is expected to open in the mid-2020s.

site_title: UOB's Q3 profit rises 3.3%
summary: UOB recorded a 3.3% year-over-year increase in Q3 net profit to $730 million, driven by loans growth and stable margins. The bank's annualised earnings per share fell to $1.74, but its 9-month net profit rose 6.1% year-over-year to $2.24 billion. Loans grew 2.1% in the quarter, led by the region, which saw a 4.4% increase excluding currency effects. UOB is confident of achieving low to mid-teens loans growth for 2013, with a focus on improving efficiency and risk management in its regional banking platform.

site_title: Pirates' share of loot - just 1-2.5%
summary: Pirates off the Horn of Africa are estimated to pocket 1-2.5% of ransom money, spending it on luxuries while financiers keep up to 75%. A joint report by the World Bank, Interpol, and UN's crime unit reveals piracy has evolved into transnational networks, costing the global economy $18 billion. From 2005-2012, pirates collected $400 million from 179 hijacked ships, using rocket-propelled grenades and tracking devices. This has allowed pirates to thrive and expand their operations, posing a threat to international shipping and regional economies.

site_title: Viking jumps on plans to enter rig business
summary: Viking Offshore & Marine has received investor approval to enter the offshore rig-building and charter market. The company will partner with local rig-building veteran Chan Kwan Bian to build a drilling jack-up rig at a cost of US$180 million. Viking will also issue 40 million new shares to Tan Boy Tee, with an option to purchase more shares within 90 days. Despite a 37% drop in third-quarter net profit, investors focused on the company's long-term opportunities in the new sector, driving a 62.2% increase in stock price.

site_title: Local banks' Q3 earnings boosted by loans growth
summary: Singapore's three local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, reported strong Q3 earnings despite a volatile September. DBS posted a net profit of $862 million, up 1% year on year, while OCBC's net profit fell 59% to $759 million. UOB reported a 15.8% year-on-year growth in loans and a stable net interest margin. The banks attributed their earnings growth to broad-based customer-related businesses and strong loan expansion. DBS expects 15% full-year 2013 loan growth and 8-10% for 2014, while UOB expects low to mid-teens loan growth.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's October PMI suggests a strong Q4 growth, despite labor market challenges. Changi Airport's Terminal 4 will incorporate design and technology for efficient operations. Temasek appoints deputy chairman Cheng Wai Keung. Local banks posted strong Q3 earnings, while Singapore Exchange trading slowed in October. China aims for 7.2% economic growth to maintain job stability, and the EU trimmed its GDP forecast for next year.

site_title: Cosco Q3 profit slides 84% to $4.2m
summary: COSCO Corporation posted an 84% decline in Q3 net profit to $4.2 million due to lower contributions from dry bulk shipping and shipyard operations. Despite a 6% year-on-year increase in turnover to $989.4 million, earnings per share fell to 0.19 cents. Turnover from shipyard operations rose 5.7% to $976 million, driven by marine engineering revenue. The group's order book stands at $7.2 billion, subject to revision from new or cancelled orders.

site_title: BBR cautious despite Q3 profit jump
summary: BBR Holdings reported a 161% increase in revenue to $120.2 million in the third quarter, with net profit more than tripling to $8.4 million. The company attributed the growth to active construction projects, but expressed caution about market conditions due to a slower construction sector growth and increasing competition. BBR expects to remain profitable for 2013 and has an order book of about $1 billion. The company's chief executive, Andrew Tan, vowed to manage costs and improve operational efficiency to stay competitive.

site_title: StarHub goes into public service broadcasts
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean pay-TV operator, has entered the public service broadcast (PSB) arena with the Media Development Authority's (MDA) Public Service Broadcast Contestable Funds Scheme (PCFS) providing up to $6 million in funding. StarHub will produce up to 100 hours of PSB content, primarily airing on its self-packaged channels E City and SuperSports Arena. The content will initially be available to StarHub subscribers but will be made available for free six months later. This move aims to introduce competition to the broadcast sector and showcase StarHub's commitment to local content production.

site_title: LA int'l airport shooting exposes security flaws
summary: A Transportation Security Administration officer was fatally shot at Los Angeles International Airport in November 2013, highlighting security flaws outside the airport's perimeter. Officials and lawmakers are exploring ways to prevent similar incidents, but may face practical limits on security upgrades. Experts acknowledge that some level of risk is unavoidable in an open society, where large public areas are not screened for weapons. This incident has revived the debate on restrictions Americans are willing to accept in exchange for greater safety.

site_title: JES investing in Xinjiang mining firm
summary: JES International, a loss-making Chinese shipbuilder, is investing $127 million in Mineriver, a Singapore-incorporated mining exploration firm with Xinjiang mining rights. This investment represents 89.15% of Mineriver's market capitalization. JES aims to diversify its earnings stream with this deal, which involves a restructuring of Mineriver to hold the Xinjiang company.

site_title: SembMarine Q3 net up 12.3%
summary: SembMarine Q3 net profit rose 12.3% to $129.7 million, driven by higher operating profit and foreign exchange gains. The company's three-month turnover surged 86% to $1.66 billion, attributed to revenue contributions from the rig building and repair sectors. Earnings per share increased to 6.21 cents from 5.53 cents previously.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Q3 net profit falls 10% to $27.2m
summary: Chip Eng Seng, a construction group, reported a 10% drop in Q3 net profit to $27.2 million, with revenue down 65.8% to $89.9 million. The decline was largely due to the company's property development segment, which saw revenue fall to $21.8 million. However, pre-tax profit was boosted by a $27.9 million share of results from associates, driven by a completed joint venture development. The company has seven wholly owned projects and a construction order book of $600 million.

site_title: Higher payouts seen for 19 of 30 STI stocks
summary: Markit Dividend Research expects 19 of 30 STI stocks to increase payouts in the next 12 months, with three expected to pay special dividends. However, dividend yields are expected to fall, particularly in banks and telcos, due to rising share prices. The top yielders are trusts and SPH, with projected yields of 6.83% and 5.50% respectively. Banks are expected to edge up on dividends but yields will trend lower, with OCBC and DBS Group Holdings projected to fall 24 and 42 basis points respectively.

site_title: Ryanair looks to soften 'macho' image
summary: Ryanair has revised its annual profit forecast to between 500 million euros and 520 million euros due to lower fares, cutting its initial forecast by 50 million euros. The airline aims to soften its "macho" image by introducing changes such as a simplified website and allowing passengers to carry an extra bag of hand luggage from December. CEO Michael O'Leary has acknowledged the need to improve customer service and reduce the airline's abrasive culture, following a series of high-profile controversies.

site_title: UK banks return to commercial property
summary: UK banks have returned to commercial property lending, narrowing lending margins by up to 2 percentage points as competition increases. Private-equity firms, pension funds, and insurers face dwindling returns on loans due to record-low gilt yields. Banks are now willing to offer loans for offices, stores, and industrial properties, with loan volumes expected to rise. The UK commercial property market has seen a recovery, with values rising for the first time since 2011, attracting banks back to the loan market.

site_title: More engaging face of the Fed
summary: Janet Yellen, nominated by President Obama to be the next Fed chairman, is expected to lead a consensus-driven and communicative Fed. Unlike her predecessors, Yellen's approach emphasizes collaboration and transparency. Her proposed policy approaches, including a balanced rule and optimal control, aim to address low employment levels and inflation. However, the success of these approaches depends on credibility and market understanding, raising concerns about "time inconsistency" and the potential for disconnects between Fed intentions and market reactions. Despite these challenges, Yellen's openness and willingness to advance the discussion of Fed policymaking are seen as positives.

site_title: SGX should consult public on HFT
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to introduce high-frequency trading (HFT) to the local equities market, sparking concerns among retail players and brokers. Despite potential benefits, the exchange should address the lack of understanding of HFT among market players, fears of losing livelihoods, and issues of fairness and accessibility. Education and a public consultation on safeguards, such as a HFT tax, may be necessary to mitigate concerns and ensure a level playing field.

site_title: US factory orders fall 1.3% in Sept
summary: US factory orders fell 1.3% in September, exceeding the previously estimated 1.1% decline, suggesting businesses may have held back investment plans due to the debt default debate. The Commerce Department reported a sharp cut in non-military capital goods orders, which could keep the Federal Reserve's bond-buying stimulus program intact. The S&P 500 has risen for four straight weeks, with 76% of index members beating profit estimates and 54% exceeding sales projections.

site_title: SATS Q2 profit down 3.2%
summary: SATS Ltd reported a 3.2% decrease in net profit to $48.7 million for the second quarter ended Sept 30, 2013, due to a 2% fall in revenue to $452.1 million, despite a 1% decline in operating expenditure to $405.5 million. The decline in revenue was attributed to a weaker yen affecting SATS's Japan-based unit, TFK Corporation.

site_title: Sky One narrows H1 loss; still studying planned RTO
summary: Sky One Holdings reported a smaller half-year net loss of HK$1.2 million (S$192,313) due to weak demand for its express land transport and air freight arms. Despite this, the company is cautiously optimistic about its new coal logistics business, citing high demand for energy and coal resources. Sky One continues to study a planned reverse takeover by Indonesian coal mining business Energy Prima and is modestly upbeat about its acquired coal logistics business.

site_title: Outages at certain SPH websites yesterday
summary: The websites of The Straits Times, The Business Times, and AsiaOne, owned by Singapore Press Holdings, experienced outages on Sunday and Monday. The company attributed the issue to technical difficulties and apologized for the inconvenience. The SPH Information Technology Division is investigating the matter.

site_title: Jurong hotel, Tiong Bahru condo among projects to get URA nod
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has granted provisional permission to several development projects, including a 560-room hotel in Jurong, a condo in Tiong Bahru, and office and retail developments in Jurong East and Tanjong Pagar. The projects, which include Keppel Land's Keppel Towers and GE Tower site, received URA approval in the third quarter. The developments are expected to launch in the first half of next year, with prices ranging from $1,162.86 to $1,167.35 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr).

site_title: Hiap Hoe Q3 net swells to $33.3m
summary: Hiap Hoe's third quarter net profit more than doubled to $33.3 million, driven by progressive revenue recognition from residential projects. Revenue jumped 98.6% to $81.1 million. The company expects the Singapore property sector to remain challenging and plans to step up marketing efforts. Hiap Hoe also made its maiden overseas foray, acquiring developments in Melbourne. The company's net profit for the nine-month period rose 65.2% to $72.8 million.

site_title: Singapore-Mauritius partnership takes off
summary: Singapore and Mauritius have partnered to create a cutting-edge national identification card, with Singapore providing expertise and funding. The card, launched in October, contains an electronic chip storing fingerprint and biometric data, addressing previous issues with incomplete and incorrect data sets. The partnership is part of Singapore Cooperation Enterprise (SCE) projects, which aim to generate economic spin-offs for the private sector. SCE has also collaborated on a light rail transit system, prison security framework, and water management processes, with plans to integrate the ID card with future e-government systems.

site_title: SuperBowl Q3 profit slumps 61.3% on higher costs
summary: SuperBowl Holdings reported a 61.3% decline in Q3 net profit to $1.1 million, despite an 8% revenue increase to $4.57 million. The decline was primarily due to higher staff costs and operating expenses. The company's bowling business grew 17.4% year-on-year, while property rental income rose 6.2%. For the nine-month period, profit fell 66.6% to $3.23 million, with staff costs and operating expenses contributing to the decline.

site_title: Airline share values in Asia weak, says Iata
summary: Airline shares worldwide rose 5% in October, outperforming the broader market. However, Asia-Pacific carriers, including Singapore Airlines, Tigerair, and Cathay Pacific, saw weaker financial performance reflected in their share values. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) reported flat global passenger traffic in September but optimistic growth in air freight markets, which have been stabilizing since April. Global fares remained stable, but have been declining since 2011. Jet fuel prices held steady at $125 per barrel.

site_title: The last great frontier: Africa markets and resources
summary: Singapore companies are increasingly investing in Africa, driven by the continent's vast resources and growing demographics. With over half of Africa's population under 20 and rapid urbanization, businesses are seeing opportunities in infrastructure, consumer goods, and healthcare. Africa is expected to be the last great frontier for business, with the International Monetary Fund predicting half of the world's 20 fastest-growing economies will come from the continent. Currently, there are around 55 Singapore companies operating in Africa, with many more expected to join, fueled by Africa's abundant resources, growing spending power, and potential for development.

site_title: Medini likely to get exemption from gains tax
summary: The Iskandar Regional Development Authority (IRDA) is likely to secure an exemption from real property gains tax (RPGT) for Medini, a special economic zone in Iskandar Malaysia. The move aims to attract investors to the hub, which already offers various incentives. However, this would result in an uneven playing field and could be seen as unfair to buyers and developers outside Medini. The exemption is expected to be granted subject to certain terms and conditions, and would not apply to other special zones, such as 1MDB's Tun Razak Exchange (TRX).

site_title: Ascott Reit to raise $253.7m in rights issue
summary: Ascott Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, is launching a $253.7 million rights issue to raise funds for debt repayment and capital expenditure. Existing unitholders are being offered a discount of 22.5% on the rights units, which will be used to pay down debt (80.8%) and fund growth initiatives (17.7%). The rights issue is expected to enhance the company's financial flexibility and trading liquidity. The new rights units are expected to list on Dec 12.

site_title: Air France sets tough terms for Alitalia: report
summary: Air France-KLM has set tough conditions for investing in loss-making Italian airline Alitalia, including 5,000 job cuts, removal of the board of directors, and a 70-80% reduction in debt of nearly €1 billion. The conditions were dictated around 10 days ago, according to an Italian newspaper, and are more than double what Alitalia's CEO had initially planned. Air France-KLM has already approved a €300 million capital increase for Alitalia, but is not obligated to participate and has set strict conditions for any further investment.

site_title: Companies not coping well with crises in digital age: Freshfields
summary: A global study by Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer found that 28% of crisis incidents spread internationally within an hour, and 67% within 24 hours, highlighting the fast-paced nature of news in the digital age. Companies took an average of 21 hours to respond to crises, and 53% of cases remained in the public eye for months. The study also revealed that over 40% of firms had no crisis plan in place, and 1 in 5 had not run a simulation exercise, leaving them vulnerable to "trial by Twitter" and significant reputational damage.

site_title: There's still scope for Singapore firms to venture into Africa
summary: Singaporean companies may still have opportunities to venture into Africa despite China's growing presence, according to experts. While China has invested heavily in Africa, Singapore's expertise and advisory services are valued, particularly in areas such as water management and urban planning. Rwanda, in particular, has enlisted Singapore's expertise in masterplanning for its capital city, Kigali. Singapore companies can leverage China's experience in Africa and partner with the China Development Bank to tap into the market.

site_title: Cuba trade fair showcases Mariel Port project
summary: The 31st Havana International Trade Fair opened on November 3, 2013, with a focus on Cuba's Mariel Port special development zone, aiming to attract foreign investment. Over 1,400 companies from 60 countries, including Spain, Venezuela, and South Korea, are attending the week-long fair. The Mariel Port, set to become a major Caribbean container shipping hub after the Panama Canal expansion in 2015, is the central attraction. New products, including rum and cigars, are also being presented at the fair.

site_title: Heineken free to sell soft drinks here
summary: Heineken International has been cleared to sell soft drinks in Singapore after Fraser and Neave (F&N) voluntarily lifted a non-compete agreement. The deal was struck in 2012 as part of F&N's sale to Heineken. F&N cited the time and resources required to negotiate with the Competition Commission and the ban's expiration in a year's time. The move highlights F&N's significant presence in Singapore's beverage market, where it competes with Yeo Hiap Seng.

site_title: The H-share market
summary: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange reported a total of 151 companies with a combined market capitalization of HK$4.64 trillion (S$743 billion) at the end of September. Many H-share stocks are related to finance and commodities, with the largest five stocks being China Construction Bank, Industrial and Commercial Bank, and state-owned oil and gas company PetroChina. Some companies, such as Bank of China and Chongqing Rural Commercial Bank, are trading at discounts to their book value and earnings. Energy companies Sinopec and PetroChina reported increased profits due to a government policy allowing them to raise fuel prices.

site_title: Traders stay cautious over battered penny stocks
summary: Traders remain cautious about battered penny stocks, despite some relief in the market. Sky One Holdings, Asiasons Capital, and Blumont Group led the way with significant jumps on Friday, with Sky One Holdings rising 43% to 14.3 cents. However, regulators are reviewing the circumstances surrounding the trading of these stocks, which were previously suspended. Traders caution that the market may not be out of the woods yet, and that one-day movements should not be extrapolated into a trend. A more significant gauge of market confidence is expected next week.

site_title: Viking Q3 earnings down
summary: Viking Offshore & Marine reported a 37% decline in Q3 net profit to $227,000, down from $362,000 in the year-ago period. The company has entered into agreements with Singaporean rig building veterans Chan Kwan Bian and Tan Boy Tee to venture into the offshore rig charter and building market. Viking is partnering with China Merchant Heavy Industries to build a drilling jack-up rig at a cost of $180 million, expected to be completed within 26 months. The company also plans to place out new shares worth $3.2 million to Tan Boy Tee.

site_title: Blackstone buys 40% stake in China mall giant SCP
summary: Blackstone Group LP, the world's largest manager of alternative assets, has agreed to buy a 40% stake in Chinese shopping mall developer and operator SCP Co. This investment is part of Blackstone's US$4 billion real estate fund focused on Asia, with CEO Stephen Schwarzman seeking to tap the Chinese market driven by rising income and urbanization. The investment value exceeds US$2 billion, with ICBC International Holdings also purchasing a 6% stake.

site_title: Continuing the Santamaria legacy
summary: Regina Santamaria, daughter of late three-Michelin-starred Spanish chef Santi Santamaria, is continuing his culinary legacy with Savour Events' 4XFour pop-up restaurant. The event, featuring four award-winning international chefs, runs from Nov 8-13 in Singapore. Santamaria's team from Can Fabes will serve up old favorites, showcasing the freshest products available. The pop-up is a chance for Santamaria to rekindle her passion for cooking and explore new opportunities, with her dream of re-opening Can Fabes still on the table.

site_title: European commercial mortgage bonds still under water
summary: European commercial mortgage bonds totaling 18 billion euros are under water due to non-repayment by borrowers. A record 25% of deals are being managed by special servicers, with delinquencies at Standard & Poor's reaching an all-time high of 15 billion euros. Thousands of properties are worth less than outstanding debt, and investors face a funding gap of 65 billion euros over the next two years as refinancing needs surpass available funds.

site_title: Paying in philanthropic dollars
summary: Goldman Sachs partners have donated US$680 million, part of their pay cheques, to charity since 2007. The bank has given away over US$1.6 billion since 2008 through its corporate philanthropy efforts, including a US$100 million initiative for 10,000 under-served women entrepreneurs and a US$500 million program for 10,000 small businesses. The philanthropic efforts aim to give back to the community, particularly in the wake of the financial crisis, and are part of the bank's "GS Gives" program, where a portion of partners' compensation is allocated to charitable causes.

site_title: Enhance cyber security, IDA urges firms and individuals
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) has urged businesses and individuals to enhance their cyber security defenses amid threats to the country's online infrastructure. The IDA has tightened IT security measures for government agencies and warned of intermittent access to some government sites over the next few days due to planned maintenance. The threats were made by unknown individuals, including a YouTube video by Anonymous, which denounced Singapore's licensing regulation of news sites and threatened "aggressive cyber intrusion".

site_title: Airbus, Boeing in row over width of seats on long-haul flights
summary: A dispute has erupted between Airbus and Boeing over the width of tourist-class seats on long-haul flights, with Airbus calling for a standard of at least 18 inches (46 cm) and Boeing arguing that airlines should decide. The issue is central to the economic performance claims of new "mini-jumbo" jet designs, with Airbus claiming its 18-inch-wide seats will improve sleep quality by 53%. Boeing disputes this, saying research shows cabin experience depends on more than seat width. The dispute comes as the two planemakers vie for record orders at the upcoming Dubai Airshow.

site_title: Kerridge returns for second helping
summary: Tom Kerridge, a renowned British chef, is in Singapore for a 20-day pop-up event, 4XFour, showcasing his signature "proper pub food." This is his second visit to the city, following a stint 1.5 years ago. Kerridge's menu features down-to-earth, unpretentious dishes, carefully scaled down to accommodate Singapore's hot climate. The event, which runs from November 3 to 13, has sold out dinner seats, with lunch seats available on select days. Kerridge's goal is to promote British pubs and his own restaurant, The Hand and Flowers, which has maintained its two Michelin stars.

site_title: BOJ's monetary policy seen fuelling property bubble
summary: The Bank of Japan's monetary policy is seen as fueling a property bubble, with Tokyo being less vulnerable to a boom and bust. Analysts warn that the Bank of Japan's easy monetary policy is creating a runway for a steep take-off, leading to a crash. Rising property values in major cities, particularly in Tokyo, are threatening the creditworthiness of banks, with Standard & Poor's warning of potential asset bubbles and imbalances. The global economy is experiencing property-price inflation, with several countries facing warning signs, but policymakers' confidence in avoiding another boom and bust could be tested if central banks continue to pump out nearly free money.

site_title: Nokia maps its future after handset sales
summary: Nokia is shifting its focus to its Here mapping division after selling its handset business to Microsoft next year. Here's a mapping division with huge potential, targeting every device, including the web, phones, tablets, and in-car navigation devices. Nokia's maps assets, acquired in 2008, provide data for services like Yahoo Maps and Bing Maps. Here's investing in new technology to compete with Google, and has already partnered with car makers and governments. The division sees growth ahead, with plans for augmented reality, voice recognition, and real-time updates.

site_title: China recovery boosts cranemaker Yongmao's Q2
summary: China-based crane maker Yongmao Holdings reported a 76.4% increase in net profit to 14.9 million yuan (S$3 million) for its Q2 2013, driven by higher sales to China and Middle East markets. Quarterly revenue rose 28.1% to 232.1 million yuan, with China sales up 42% and Middle East sales more than seven times higher. The company expects stronger domestic sales in China due to a steadying economy and potential higher demand for its towercranes in infrastructure projects.

site_title: Japan's proposed secrecy bill is disquieting
summary: Japan's proposed secrecy bill, aimed at toughening penalties for leaking state secrets, has sparked public opposition, with 50.6% of the public against it. The bill, submitted by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government, is intended to protect confidential information for national security, but advocates of constitutional democracy fear it could restrict public access to information on sensitive issues such as the Fukushima nuclear crisis and tensions with China. The bill's timing coincides with the government's revisions to the pacifistic Constitution, further raising concerns about the erosion of individual citizens' rights.

site_title: Genting lifts Q3 profit; looks to Japan deal
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 75% surge in Q3 net profit to $193 million, driven by strong gaming and non-gaming segments. Revenue climbed 16% to $776.8 million. The company expects Japan to liberalize casinos between January and April, with a possible share of the market. Genting's gaming revenue rose 15% to $606.7 million, while non-gaming revenues increased 27% to $169.7 million. The company's adjusted Ebitda grew 15% to $347.4 million.

site_title: Refining and enhancing existing SME schemes
summary: Singapore's government will focus on refining and enhancing existing Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SME) schemes rather than introducing new ones. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Teo Ser Luck emphasized the need for effective implementation and simplification of existing schemes to avoid confusion and overwhelm for SMEs. The government aims to streamline schemes and provide more support to SMEs, including cost advantages and industry-specific initiatives, while encouraging them to take an active role in tapping into available resources.

site_title: Demand for Jakarta offices lures overseas investors
summary: Foreign investors are increasingly seeking premium office space in Jakarta, driven by the city's booming economy and infrastructure projects. Despite being barred from owning property, foreign companies are partnering with local firms to secure office space. A recent example is Singapore's GIC teaming up with Indonesian investment house Rajawali Group to buy the St Regis office tower. Office vacancy rates are expected to remain low, with minimal space available for rent, and rents are expected to grow by 25% this year. The surge in demand is also driven by Jakarta's affordable office rents, which are among the region's cheapest.

site_title: US banks get new set of stress tests scenarios
summary: The Federal Reserve has introduced new stress test scenarios for US banks in 2014, reflecting emerging asset bubbles and counterparty credit risk concerns. The tests will assess banks' ability to survive a trading partner collapse, a decline in high-risk loans, or a housing bust. Twelve banks will undergo capital reviews, including six with large trading operations that must test their portfolios against a global financial shock. The tests aim to build resiliency against economic shocks and prevent a repeat of the 2008 crisis.

site_title: Dutch government to cash in on ING bonds
summary: The Dutch government is planning to sell $12 billion in mortgage bonds acquired from ING Groep NV during the 2009 bailout, which have seen their value more than double. The bonds, tied to high-risk borrowers, are currently valued at 71% of their face amount, potentially yielding a gain of almost $800 million. The sales, requiring EU approval, aim to be completed within a year, amid risks including the US Federal Reserve's economic stimulus reduction and potential sales by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

site_title: The 'crazy' gardener
summary: Landscape artist Kazuyuki Ishihara, a Japanese man, observes visitors at Gardens by the Bay to improve his landscape displays. He takes note of which angles and flowers visitors like, aiming to create a more appealing experience. Ishihara believes that no garden is perfect and values feedback from visitors to enhance his work. By doing so, he aims to create a more enjoyable and personalized experience for those who visit his displays.

site_title: Embraer probed for bribery in plane deals
summary: US and Brazilian authorities are investigating Embraer SA for allegedly bribing officials in Argentina and the Dominican Republic to secure deals for commercial and defense aircraft. The probe involves 20 passenger jets sold to an Argentine state airline and eight Super Tucano light attack planes sold to the Dominican armed forces. Embraer has cooperated with authorities and declined to comment on details of the allegations, which could result in substantial fines or sanctions.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore companies have established a foothold in Africa, with several firms investing in the continent. Analysts warn of a potential Tokyo property bubble due to the Bank of Japan's monetary policy. The IDA urges businesses to enhance online security measures against cyber attacks. The majority of STI stocks are expected to increase dividends. Genting Singapore reported healthy Q3 earnings, while Iskandar Waterfront has postponed its IPO due to slow demand. The PBOC plans to drain cash from markets over the next two months. Twitter's IPO performance will influence the valuation of emerging Web start-ups.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: KREUZ Holdings reported a 60.3% year-on-year surge in third-quarter net profit to US$16.6 million, with revenue increasing 69% to US$76.9 million. This translates to earnings per share of 2.98 US cents, up from 1.86 US cents a year earlier.

site_title: Alliance launches ICT education initiative
summary: Cisco launches the Global STEM Alliance with the New York Academy of Sciences to provide curriculum resources, mentorship, and access to cutting-edge research for STEM education globally. The alliance, starting with Malaysia and Barcelona, aims to address the growing need for trained IT manpower, with 222,000 more technical graduates needed annually between 2014 and 2022 to meet the projected talent gap of 8.2% by 2022.

site_title: Chemical tankers in demand as shale-driven US exports soar
summary: US chemical production, driven by cheap natural gas, is fueling a surge in chemical exports, creating a shortage of tankers and driving up profits for owners such as Ardmore Shipping Corp and Stolt-Nielsen Ltd. With limited global fleet capacity, companies can command higher rates, and analysts expect a 5-6% annual rise in global demand for chemical tankers over the next three years. This shortage is expected to peak in 2015, benefiting tanker operators with ships already on the water.

site_title: A re-look at China stocks?
summary: China's top leadership may unveil major reforms, potentially reviving investor interest in the country's stocks, which have been languishing due to a slowing economy and lack of confidence in the financial system. The Shanghai Stock Exchange Composite Index is near 2009 lows, and the Shenzhen Stock Exchange Composite Index is off its peaks since 2010. A re-rating of Chinese stocks is possible if investors see concrete actions and details from the upcoming Third Plenum meeting, which will outline China's priorities and potentially include reforms on the banking system, land-use, and local government debt.

site_title: Director, buyback activity declines
summary: Singapore Exchange saw a decline in director buyback activity, with 18 companies recording 30 transactions worth $5.5 million from Oct 28 to Nov 1. Buyers outnumbered sellers with 14 companies purchasing $4.8 million, while sellers had only three firms disposing of $768,000. This was a decrease from the previous week's 19 firms and $9.5 million.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for Trade and Industry, Teo Ser Luck, has stated that industrialists leasing factories at JTC must show improved productivity to have their leases renewed. Meanwhile, more Singaporeans are moving to Silicon Valley for work, citing reasons beyond higher salaries. Indonesian economy growth is forecast to slow to a four-year low in Q3, while China's services sector expanded at its fastest pace in 13 months in October. Climate change is expected to pose risks to global food supply, and China investors are losing interest in Brazil.

site_title: Waiting for a big event to scale new heights
summary: US stocks rose for the fourth consecutive week, driven by strong third-quarter earnings from tech companies like Netflix and Facebook. However, retail sales and labor market data may indicate a slowdown ahead of the holiday season due to government shutdowns affecting consumer spending. Economists expect a 0.4% sales growth in October and a possible rise in the unemployment rate to 7.4%. The market is also watching the upcoming IPO of Twitter, which could boost enthusiasm and drive stock performance.

site_title: The Valley of choice for Singapore professionals
summary: Singaporeans are increasingly moving to Silicon Valley for work, driven by high salaries, flexible hours, and a progressive culture. IT and engineering professionals command higher salaries, but others cite other reasons for making the move. The number of Singaporeans in SV is expected to increase as the local network grows stronger, encouraging more to take the leap. This trend is attributed to the efforts of incubators like Golden Gate Ventures, which has offices in both Singapore and SV.

site_title: Sony shares slump after profit-forecast cut, Q2 loss
summary: Sony shares plummeted 11% after CEO Kazuo Hirai cut his earnings forecast by 40% due to poor sales of TVs, cameras, and Hollywood movies, posting a Q2 loss. The company's film unit lost money, and five of its nine divisions posted operating losses. Fitch Ratings advises Sony to reduce costs and launch more aggressive products and business reform. Analysts predict a drastic recovery hinges on Sony's ability to draft a reform plan, with some cutting their share price forecast.

site_title: IoT - a US$14t opportunity by '20?
summary: Industry leaders at the IoT World Forum in Barcelona pledge to work together to implement standards for the Internet of Things (IoT), a technology expected to generate $14.4 trillion in profits by 2020. By 2020, an estimated 212 billion devices are expected to be connected to the internet, generating 40 trillion gigabytes of data. Cisco Chairman John Chambers emphasizes the need for open standards to enable devices to "talk to each other," and the company has committed $1 billion to IoT development this year, with plans to spend another billion over the next five years.

site_title: Jubilee: An interesting Iskandar play
summary: Jubilee Industries Holdings, a plastic injection mould producer, is set to undergo a reverse takeover (RTO) in Singapore, with Singaporean businessman Dennis Ng injecting Tenderside Ventures into the company. Tenderside will gain a 54% stake in Jubilee after acquiring the company's shares for RM150 million. The deal is expected to boost Jubilee's issued shares to around 508 million. Jubilee owns a stake in Viridea Lakeside Sdn Bhd, which will acquire the Viridea @ Medini Lakeside project in Johor, generating a profit of RM180 million for Jubilee. The RTO process is expected to take around half a year, and investors should note the long-term economic sustainability and political stability of the Iskandar region.

site_title: Productivity to play role in JTC lease renewals
summary: Singapore's JTC (Jurong Town Corporation) will require industrialists to submit a proposal on how they intend to raise efficiency levels and set milestones when renewing their leases. The goal is to create a win-win situation, where land use can be intensified in space-starved Singapore, while companies can benefit by becoming more productive. Companies will need to demonstrate automation and other productivity measures to secure lease renewals, with the aim of strengthening small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

site_title: Penny stock collapse sucks life out of market
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has taken action against three penny stocks, Asiasons, Blumont, and Liongold, designating them as speculative and suspending trading for two weeks. This move has led to a significant decline in trading volume and a grim mood in trading rooms. The Straits Times Index fell 9.47 points to 3,201.2, and blue-chip stocks also declined. The action by SGX has paralyzed the market, with retail brokers reporting little interest from clients. The market's downturn is attributed to concerns over the Fed's monetary stimulus and global economic worries.

site_title: Fashion goes fast with speedier adoption of 3D
summary: French 3D software developer Dassault Systemes reports that the fashion world has rapidly adopted 3D modelling technology, with most Paris designers now incorporating 3D technology into their workflow just two years after launching FashionLab, a research arm focused on the fashion space. Initially forecasting a 5-year adoption period, FashionLab director Jerome Bergeret notes that designers have moved from 2D sketches to 3D design technology at an accelerated pace. This shift is seen as a significant milestone in the fashion industry's transition to 3D design.

site_title: DP Architects calls the shots in Dubai
summary: DP Architects, a Singapore-based firm, designed the world's largest mall, The Dubai Mall, which boasts a 6 million sq ft gross floor area and welcomed 65 million visitors in 2013. The mall is set to expand by 1 million sq ft, aiming to reach 100 million annual visitors. DP Architects' deputy CEO, Angelene Chan, attributes the success to ease of circulation, operational efficiency, and clear way-finding, while also overcoming challenges such as Dubai's extreme climate and seismic activity. The expansion is a testament to the mall's success and the need for retailers to stay competitive with an increasing "refresh rate" of shopping malls.

site_title: Off the bitten track
summary: Wolf, a Singaporean restaurant inspired by the nose-to-tail philosophy of chef Fergus Henderson, offers a unique dining experience that explores the lesser-known parts of the animal. The menu features dishes like beef hearts, pig's ears, and chicken livers, with some standout items including the house-made pig's head and trotter brawn and the oxtail and lips stew. However, some dishes fall short, such as the "grilled" ox tongue and the wood-smoked kurobuta pork chop. Despite its limitations, Wolf's solid staff, slick surroundings, and clever wall-etchings make it a polished eatery that is worth visiting. Rating: 7.

site_title: Rare Goldman view on US economy
summary: Goldman Sachs President Gary Cohn expects the US Federal Reserve to begin tapering monetary stimulus in the second half of 2014, but only if the US economy improves. Cohn believes the US economy is sluggish, with a deleveraged consumer and underwhelming corporate earnings. He also notes that Washington's budget problems hinder economic growth. Cohn emphasizes the importance of corporate tax reform, immigration reform, and addressing offshore money issues. He expects the Fed to delay tapering until next summer due to the government shutdown and holiday season's impact on economic data.

site_title: S'pore most important friend of US in region: envoy
summary: US Ambassador to Singapore Kirk Wagar calls Singapore the most important friend the US has in the region due to a relationship of trust built with Washington. Singapore acts as a key adviser for the US, providing guidance and partnerships in South-east Asia. The US values Singapore's example of open markets, rule of law, and economic growth. The US-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (USSFTA) is considered the best-performing FTA signed by the US, with Singapore emerging as a top 10 trading partner. Wagar prioritizes the completion and implementation of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) in his posting.

site_title: CAO's Q3 profit up 65%, lifted by associates
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 65% increase in Q3 net profit to US$21.8 million, driven by a significant rise in associate companies' profits, particularly from Shanghai Pudong International Airport Aviation Fuel Supply. Revenue fell 3% to US$3.7 billion due to lower trading volume and product mix. CAO's CEO, Meng Fanqiu, stated the company remains focused on its long-term goal of becoming a global transportation fuels provider by 2020. The company plans to expand globally and acquire or invest in synergistic business assets.

site_title: French football clubs to go ahead with strike
summary: French football clubs will proceed with a historic strike from November 29 to December 2, rejecting President Francois Hollande's refusal to exempt them from a 75% tax on high earners. The tax, aimed at reducing France's budget deficit, will affect income earned this year and in 2014, and will cost Ligue 1 clubs approximately 44 million euros. The strike, which has not been called off despite Hollande's invitation to work on a "durable and balanced economic model," will be the first for French football since 1972.

site_title: Small city, big draws
summary: Asheville, North Carolina, a small city in the Blue Ridge Mountains, has become a popular destination for travelers, particularly those from Singapore. The city's natural beauty, outdoor recreational activities, and unique attractions such as the Biltmore Estate, a 250-room chateau-style mansion, draw visitors. The city's restaurants, including 12 Bones, famous for its slow-smoked ribs, and Nine Mile, a Caribbean-inspired eatery, offer excellent food options. Asheville is also known for its craft beer scene, with Wicked Weed Brewing producing tens of thousands of barrels of beer annually. The city's small-town charm and affordability make it an attractive alternative to big cities like New York or Boston.

site_title: Gradual China recovery seen as Oct PMI jumps
summary: China's manufacturing sector expanded in October, with the official PMI reaching an 18-month peak of 51.4, and a separate PMI index published by HSBC and Markit rising to a seven-month high of 50.9. The data suggests a stabilisation of the economy, but analysts question the strength and sustainability of the recovery, citing an investment and export-dependent growth model. The economy grew 7.8% year on year in Q3 and is expected to moderate to 7.5% in the last quarter.

site_title: Big protests as Thai MPs pass political amnesty bill
summary: Thai MPs passed a political amnesty bill, sparking protests and fears it will allow fugitive former premier Thaksin Shinawatra to return home. The bill, which still needs upper house approval, has been criticized for potentially "whitewashing" past abuses, including the killing of unarmed protesters. Thousands protested in Bangkok, with the opposition Democrat Party refusing to participate in the vote. The bill's passage has raised concerns of another civil unrest in a country with a history of political violence, with human rights groups warning it would allow officials to go unpunished for alleged abuses.

site_title: Top 100 wines revealed
summary: Luxury magazine The Peak Selections: Gourmet and Travel unveiled its annual G Top 100 Wine list, recognizing the growing importance of wines to its readers. Over 200 labels from 12 countries were submitted by 31 importer-distributors for judging by a panel of 14 seasoned palates. The top 12 wines were announced, with Sato Pinot Noir 2011 as the Most Drinkable Red Wine and Vega Sicilia Alion 2007 as the Red Wine of the Year. The list aims to serve all wine enthusiasts, whether an aficionado or a beginner.

site_title: DBS net profit for Q3 flat at $862m
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a Q3 net profit of $862 million, beating estimates of $828 million and $839 million. The profit increased 1% year-over-year but decreased 3% quarter-over-quarter due to a 20% drop in non-interest income. The decline was attributed to incorrect market expectations on interest rate tapering.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Olam International sold its Dirranbandi cotton gin in Queensland for A$20 million. Lindeteves-Jacoberg was removed from the SGX watch-list. Otto Marine sold two vessels to PT GO Marine International for US$95 million and US$25 million. Jaya Holdings appointed Wong Siu Min as its new chairman. Dyna-mac secured US$117 million orders from Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering and OneSubsea Malaysia Systems.

site_title: OCBC's Q3 net profit falls 59% in absence of divestment gains
summary: OCBC's third-quarter net profit fell 59% to $759 million, excluding a one-time divestment gain. Core net profit rose 5% to $759 million, beating estimates, driven by higher fee income and insurance profitability. Customer loans rose 16% to $162 billion, while net interest margin declined to 1.63%. The bank expects growth in overseas markets, particularly in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Greater China, and will deepen its presence in these regions.

site_title: Bucking the trend
summary: Three F&B establishments, The Provision Shop, The Beast, and Cafe Ergo Sum, have successfully expanded and opened new outlets despite stiff competition and labor shortages. The Provision Shop, a gourmet deli, offers a unique blend of Italian, American, and Polish influences, while The Beast, an informal southern American kitchen and specialty bourbon whiskey bar, features Southern comfort fare and over 30 types of bourbon whiskey. Cafe Ergo Sum, a sandwich bar, has relocated to Duxton Hill with a larger space and expanded menu. Meanwhile, Marukyu, a Japanese restaurant, has opened in the CBD area, capitalizing on the growing demand for dining options near the new Telok Ayer MRT station.

site_title: Better support policies for social enterprises
summary: A recent dialogue in Berlin brought together European and Asian policy influencers and social entrepreneurs to discuss better support policies for social enterprises (SEs). Despite Asia's growing interest in social enterprise, many countries still lack specific policy support, financial sustainability, and capacity to assist SEs. Experts emphasized the need for governments to provide clearer definitions, architectures, and supportive frameworks for SEs, including tax relief and start-up capital. The dialogue highlighted the potential for Asia and Europe to collaborate and learn from each other to create a better business environment for SEs, with the goal of promoting inclusive and sustainable growth.

site_title: Oxley makes inroads into London with £200m property deal
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based developer, has acquired a 40-acre site in London's Royal Wharf area for £200 million, planning over 3,400 homes and commercial, retail, leisure, and educational facilities. The deal is part of Oxley's aggressive overseas expansion and comes as London faces a housing shortage. The purchase is seen as a significant investment by Oxley, with CEO Ching Chiat Kwong calling it an "outstanding opportunity" to create a vibrant district in London.

site_title: CH Offshore's Q1 net dives 20% to US$7.4m as revenue shrinks
summary: CH Offshore reported a 19.7% decline in net profit to US$7.4 million for the first quarter, with revenue falling 40.3% to US$7.9 million. Lower utilisation and charter rates for two vessels contributed to the decline. The company's earnings per share dropped to 1.05 US cents from 1.30 US cents last year. A reversal of a provision and lower operating costs partially offset the decline. Cash generated from operations was US$5.92 million, with cash and cash equivalents increasing 7.8% to US$70.8 million.

site_title: Making the right decision
summary: Repeated exposure to high doses of diagnostic radiation for heart disease can be harmful, increasing the risk of cancer. Studies have shown that high radiation exposure, such as from cardiac procedures, can lead to a doubling of radiation doses over the years, with an average cumulative radiation dose of about 19 mSv in the first two years after a heart attack. However, the benefits of cardiac diagnostic and therapeutic procedures, including opening blocked heart arteries, outweigh the risks, especially for patients with chest symptoms. Experts recommend opting for non-invasive tests, understanding radiation exposure, and considering alternative procedures like magnetic resonance imaging scans for young adults and women.

site_title: Credit Suisse ETF case shows up trading problems
summary: Credit Suisse has fired a trader over a US$6 million loss in exchange-traded funds (ETFs) trading, following a lengthy delay in disclosing the alleged loss. The bank said the trader acted alone and that no clients were impacted. The incident raises compliance concerns, particularly given the significant impact of ETF trading on individual shares and bonds. This is not the first high-profile rogue-trader incident, following a similar US$2.3 billion loss at UBS in 2011. Credit Suisse is continuing to investigate how managers and compliance officials failed to detect the losses swiftly.

site_title: Urban concepts for Congo
summary: The Republic of Congo is planning to develop four Special Economic Zones (SEZs) in Pointe Noire, Brazzaville, Oyo-Ollombo, and Quesso. Surbana, a Singaporean urban planning firm, is leading an 18-person team in creating a master plan and feasibility study for the Oyo-Ollombo SEZ. The project aims to create a green and sustainable city, with a focus on agro-business, commercial, educational, and recreational facilities. The SEZ is expected to launch early next year, pending government approval.

site_title: Pared down yet writ large
summary: A man discovers his wife's infidelity when she is caught in bed with another man. Instead of reacting angrily, the husband devises a plan to punish her by forcing her to care for the other man's abandoned suit, which becomes a "guest" in their home. The suit is fed, walked, and even given attention, as the husband seeks to humiliate and shame his wife for her infidelity. This unusual and unconventional approach to dealing with the situation has sparked both amusement and concern among readers.

site_title: Local wind orchestra's 'surround' show
summary: American composer David Ward-Steinman returns to Singapore for the world premiere of his 2012 composition, "Singapore Sonorama," at the Esplanade Concert Hall. The 16-minute piece honors various elements of Singapore, including the Merlion, Malay culture, and Chinatown. The concert, "Circus Maximus," features a full-sized wind band and additional musicians positioned throughout the concert hall to create a "surround sound" experience. Conducted by Leonard Tan, the event showcases a diverse range of musical pieces, including works by John Corgliano and Chang Su Koh.

site_title: All in: M1 raises stakes with buffet app service
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, has launched "All You Can App", a buffet-style app service in partnership with Canadian firm Mobiroo. The service offers over 800 games and apps for $5.35 a month, available on up to three Android devices per subscription. The service will be available starting next Friday and includes a seven-day free trial and free download of an Electronic Arts app. This move aims to attract customers and pave the way for greater data usage, following similar partnerships in Malaysia and plans for North America and Latin America.

site_title: UIC chalks up 8% rise in net while SingLand profit slips 13% for Q3
summary: UIC's net profit rose 8% to $43.4 million in Q3, driven by lower costs and higher income from its hotel operations. In contrast, SingLand's net profit fell 13% to $49.4 million, due to lower sales recognition and revenue decline. Both companies' year-to-date net profits were higher, with UIC's 31% surge and SingLand's 55% surge. The results were attributed to fair value gains on investment properties and higher shares of results from associated companies.

site_title: Centurion to build student accommodation in Australia
summary: Centurion Corporation has secured a deal to build student accommodation in Melbourne, Australia, for A$60 million. The project, RMIT Village, will feature 229 apartments with a current capacity of 456 beds. Centurion will fund the acquisition through medium-term notes and bank borrowings, with the deal expected to contribute to its bottom line early next year. The property is currently managed by Campus Living Village and affiliated with RMIT University, with the university reserving 70% of beds annually.

site_title: UMWOG closes almost 11% up in debut
summary: UMW Oil & Gas Corporation (UMWOG) made a successful debut on the stock exchange, with its stock closing 11% up at RM3.10, its highest point of RM3.18. The IPO raised RM2.4 billion, with institutional and retail portions oversubscribed by 55 and 11 times, respectively. The company's strong track record and Petronas licence for drilling and oilfield services contributed to its robust debut.

site_title: From Utah to Singapore - one couple's Bitcoin odyssey
summary: A newlywed couple, Austin Craig and Beccy Bingham-Craig, traveled from Utah to Singapore, paying for everything in Bitcoin over 102 days. They visited Berlin and Stockholm, meeting fellow Bitcoiners along the way. When asked if they "cheated," Beccy said they didn't, claiming it was a legitimate experiment. The couple's Bitcoin odyssey, called "Life on Bitcoin," ended in Singapore, with no direct government-backed expenses.

site_title: Cebu to add new points to long-haul flights
summary: Cebu Pacific, the Philippines' top budget carrier, plans to expand its international long-haul flights to Australia, Saudi Arabia, and Japan. The airline has ordered 49 new Airbus aircraft over an 8-year period, with a focus on 7-10 hour flights. Cebu Pacific aims to double its international long-haul flights by the end of next year, with a key challenge being managing over-capacity in the industry. The airline will pace new aircraft arrival with predicted growth, aiming for slower growth in the high single-digits.

site_title: Jazz tie-up treats
summary: Veteran jazz pianist Jeremy Monteiro is collaborating with Russian jazz musicians in the Russia-Singapore Jazz Symphonia concert at the School of the Arts. The concert features a mix of jazz and symphonic music, with Monteiro's original pieces and a nine-part symphonic suite by Enri Lolashvilli. For the second half, Monteiro's quartet will perform traditional jazz with two Russian musicians, including famed trumpeter Vadim Eilenkrig and saxophonist Igor Butman, who has been praised by Bill Clinton as one of the greatest living jazz saxophone players. The concert runs tonight at 8pm at the SOTA Concert Hall.

site_title: Aussie resource firm's move a litmus test for others
summary: Linc Energy, an Australian upstream oil and gas firm, is shifting its listing from the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in a move seen as a litmus test for other resource firms. The company has received keen interest from local and offshore investors, with its managing director stating that Singapore's ability to tap international capital and growing Asian focus make it an attractive location. The move is seen as a first-mover advantage for the firm in an emerging mineral, oil and gas cluster on SGX, with its headquarters set to move to Singapore by next month.

site_title: Basking in Ilo Ilo's afterglow
summary: Anthony Chen's debut film Ilo Ilo won the Best Film prize at the Golden Horse Awards, considered the most prestigious prize in Chinese cinema. Chen's victory marked a significant milestone for Singapore cinema, with industry veterans praising his business savvy and artistic skill. The win follows Chen's Cannes debut, where Ilo Ilo received a 15-minute standing ovation and won the Camera d'Or award. The film's success has opened doors for Singapore films, with the industry expecting a surge in recognition and funding. However, some warn that the spotlight may lead to a rush of copycats and a loss of authenticity.

site_title: Rules work much better than persuasion: KPMG/ISCA study
summary: A study by KPMG and the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants found that listed companies in Singapore comply more with rules than best-practice guidelines. 98% of companies reported internal control adequacy, but only 12% complied with the revised Code of Corporate Governance's Principle 11.3. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) prefers to "raise the reward for good behavior" rather than introducing more rules, with Deputy Chief Regulatory Officer Richard Teng stating that rules can lead to a higher adoption rate but may deter directors who truly want to serve the company.

site_title: Japan megabanks under scrutiny for alleged ties with Yakuza
summary: Japan's three megabanks, Mizuho, Mitsubishi UFJ, and Sumitomo Mitsui, are under investigation by Japan's Financial Services Agency for alleged ties with Yakuza gangs. The banks are accused of giving consumer loans to individuals linked to organized crime syndicates. The investigation is part of a broader effort to prove Japan's financial sector is "clean" and to isolate and weaken the Yakuza. Sanctions have already been imposed on 54 Mizuho executives, and inspections are underway at the two other banks, focusing on compliance practices and risk management systems.

site_title: Hedge funds bet on repeat of this year's profitable yen plunge
summary: Hedge funds are betting on another yen plunge, with net shorts reaching the highest since 2007. Futures traders are positioning for a decline in the yen versus the US dollar, despite economists predicting little change. Japan's central bank has increased monthly bond purchases to boost growth and combat deflation, causing the yen to fall 15% this year, its worst performance since 1979. Billionaires George Soros and Stan Druckenmiller also have short positions on the yen, with some speculating that a reduction in US bond purchases by the Federal Reserve could drive further yen weakness.

site_title: Shop savvy
summary: A new column on stylish indulgences is being launched, focusing on British perfume houses and luxury brands. Atkinsons is reviving its 200-year-old heritage with unique fragrances, while Hermes has unveiled a jewelry collection inspired by the Nile Crocodile, featuring mesh-jointed rose-gold scales. Fashion newcomer Joyce Wong has created intricate woven patterns for her signature dresses, and Atelier LLYER is standing out with its hand-finishing and full-grain Italian leather shoes.

site_title: Oxley unit signs JV to develop M'sian project
summary: Oxley Holdings' wholly owned subsidiary, Oxley Ruby Sdn Bhd, has signed a joint venture agreement with Peninsular Teamwork Sdn Bhd to develop a 900-unit housing estate in Malaysia's Selangor state. Oxley Ruby will bear development charges and costs, while Peninsular will receive 30% of the gross development value exceeding RM7 million. The project must be approved for 900 units with a 5% tolerance, and completion is expected within five years.

site_title: Singapore, Jamaica ink open-skies agreement
summary: Singapore and Jamaica signed an Open Skies Agreement (OSA) on Monday, allowing designated airlines to fly between the two countries and beyond a third country without restrictions. The agreement reflects the countries' commitment to a fully liberal air-services framework, enabling carriers to respond to market demand. Minister for Transport Lui Tuck Yew and Jamaica's Minister without Portfolio Morais Guy signed the agreement at the International Maritime Organisation Assembly in London. The move is seen as a step towards establishing warm bilateral ties between the two nations.

site_title: Designs on the high life in Mongolia
summary: Singaporean architect Lim Kok Hui has been working in Mongolia since March as director of Ong&Ong's Mongolia office, tasked with incorporating Singaporean urban design into the country's landscape. He is overseeing the development of Zaisan 18, a luxury mixed-use project in Ulaanbaatar, which combines condominium apartments, serviced apartments, retail amenities, and a medical clinic. Despite cultural and language challenges, Lim has fallen in love with Mongolia's fast-emerging market and is excited to be part of its development.

site_title: Square Moon sheds light on dark past
summary: Actor Lim Kay Siu recalls the 1987 Marxist Conspiracy arrests, where five theatre practitioners were detained without trial. Playwright Wong Souk Yee, a co-founder of the Third Stage, was also detained and has written a new play, Square Moon, inspired by her experiences and the 2008 escape of terrorist Mas Selamat. After being rejected by the Substation and M1 Fringe Festival, the play has been approved by the Media Development Authority and will open at the University Cultural Centre on Dec 20 with a cast of familiar faces.

site_title: CAO seeks 30% more jet fuel than usual in latest tender
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO), Asia's top jet fuel buyer, is seeking 1.6 million barrels of jet fuel for delivery from late December to January, a 30% increase from usual requirements. The tender, closing today, is for four cargoes of 240,000-300,000 barrels each from South Korea, Japan, and other countries. This increase comes after CAO halved its monthly jet fuel requirement in October due to a tax policy change.

site_title: Design takes flight
summary: Singapore architect Chan Soo Khian is bringing his Soori brand to the US with Soori High Line, a 14,813 sq ft boutique residential development in lower Manhattan's West Chelsea district. This is Chan's first project in the US, following his successful Alila Villas Soori in Bali. The 11-storey development features 27 apartments with private pools, double-volume living spaces, and fireplaces, blending Asian design concepts with NYC regulations. The project is being developed by Blackhouse Oriel Development, with Soori High Line set to launch for sale in the first quarter of 2016.

site_title: Looking ahead to the Civic and Cultural District by the Bay
summary: The Civic and Cultural District by the Bay in Singapore is set to undergo significant enhancements by 2015, including pedestrianized roads, improved landscaping, and outdoor event spaces. Existing roads will be converted into pedestrian paths, and Empress Place and Esplanade Park will receive upgrades. The district's vision includes a seamless park-like setting, a waterfront promenade with stepped plazas, and an urban beach. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's PubliCity initiative aims to engage the community in celebrating public spaces and promoting good design.

images.alt_text: HEART OF THE CITY There will be more spaces for pedestrian activities and outdoor events, and night lighting will also be provided to support night activities.

site_title: Keppel Fels bags order for US$265m rig
summary: Keppel Fels, a subsidiary of Keppel Offshore & Marine, has secured a $265 million order to build a jack-up rig for Ensco plc. This is the fourth Ensco 120 series rig ordered from Keppel Fels since 2011 and is scheduled for delivery in 2016. The rig can operate in harsh environments and has proprietary technology increasing operational efficiencies. This deal lifts Keppel O&M's year-to-date orders to $6.7 billion, with a net order book of $13.6 billion as of September.

site_title: Taking a leaf from Ceylon
summary: In Sri Lanka, tea has been a significant contributor to the country's economy since the mid-19th century. The country's highlands, particularly Nuwara Eliya, are home to some of the world's finest and most delicate tea varieties, including Ceylon tea. The tea industry is highly regulated, with most tea sold through an auction system, ensuring that estates receive the best prices for their teas. The industry's unique blend of science, math, and tradition has allowed Sri Lanka to maintain its position as a leading tea producer, with the country's tea estates still retaining their English estate names and character.

site_title: Cedar Strategic gets 36m yuan revenue boost
summary: Cedar Strategic Holdings (CSH), a Catalist-listed company, reported a 36 million yuan (S$7.4 million) revenue boost from the sale of commercial units in its development project, Xiao Cheng Gu Shi, in China's Guizhou province. The sale, which occurred in November, will contribute positively to the group's consolidated revenues for the quarter ended December 31, 2013. CSH acquired the project through its subsidiary, Guiyang Shunhe Real Estate Development, and aims to become a regional real estate player in China.

site_title: Three-minute digest
summary: INTERACTIVE Brokers is taking action against 10 clients who lost approximately US$68 million in the October penny stock collapse. Meanwhile, demonstrations in Bangkok have minimal impact on Singapore companies. China's leaders have committed to reforms to ensure future growth. OANDA is expanding into Asia after successfully reviving retail foreign exchange trading in Singapore. A new carbon market is set to launch in Guangdong, China, while ANA and Japan Airlines flew through a Chinese air defence zone without notification. US mortgage troubles continue to rise, with borrowers missing payments on home equity lines of credit.

site_title: Golden-Agri's Q3 earnings down 64.8%
summary: Golden-Agri-Resources (GAR) reported a 64.8% decline in its third-quarter net profit to US$30.2 million, down from US$85.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue dropped 6.1% to US$1.6 billion, while gross profit fell 30.3% to US$277.5 million. The company attributed the decline to weaker crude palm oil market prices, but remains confident about the palm oil industry's long-term fundamentals. GAR's board approved an interim dividend of 0.585 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: NZ central bank sees signs of mortgage curbs starting to work
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), reports that mortgage lending restrictions are starting to slow the country's over-heated housing market. A fall in home building approvals and a drop in open home attendance indicate that the limits on low-deposit lending are working. The RBNZ expects the policy to reduce annual house-price inflation by up to 4 percentage points in the first year. Governor Graeme Wheeler believes the restrictions will slow the housing market and reduce the risk of a house-price correction.

site_title: Brick & mortar retailers turn data smart
summary: Brick and mortar retailers are increasingly using technology such as face scans, heat sensors, and WiFi signals to improve marketing and sales. This includes anonymized and aggregated data tracking, with some retailers promising to use only this type of data unless shoppers give explicit permission to be tracked. Retailers like Tesco, Hugo Boss, and Godiva are using these technologies to optimize staffing, layout, and marketing, with some seeing significant increases in transactions and customer engagement. As consumers become more comfortable with being tracked, many are signing up for loyalty schemes that offer targeted discounts and personalized experiences.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: The Singapore government raised its full-year economic growth forecast to 3.5-4% for 2013. IDA approved the sale of OpenNet to SingTel's NetLink Trust for $126 million. ExxonMobil unveiled the world's first direct crude oil-to-chemicals petrochemical cracker in Singapore. Meanwhile, fund managers are seeking bargains in 2014, and Tigerair's website issues may impact sales. The Singapore government also sold a third of its stake in Australand, and President Barack Obama plans to visit Asia in April to strengthen ties.

site_title: Higher costs weigh on UEL's Q2 earnings
summary: UEL's second-quarter net profit declined 11.7% to $7.1 million due to higher costs, particularly other operating expenses and finance costs. Revenue dipped 3.6% to $52 million, but the company's recurring water treatment business saw a 56.6% increase. Despite this, UEL's first-half net profit fell 7.9% to $12.9 million. The company remains upbeat about China's water treatment market and plans to acquire more water treatment plants. Analysts maintain a "hold" on the stock, citing improved margins expected from recurring treatment revenue.

site_title: En bloc sale for The Arcade in the offing
summary: The Arcade, a 20-storey office-and-retail building in Raffles Place, Singapore, is set for a collective sale. The price tag is estimated to be around $3,000 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), with a total value of around $800 million. Owners controlling at least 80% of share value and strata area have consented to the sale, pending verification of signatures. The site has significant redevelopment potential, with a 999-year land tenure, and could be redeveloped into a more substantial site if combined with the adjacent Clifford Centre.

site_title: All in a day's work
summary: Contract employment is on the rise in Singapore due to the tightening of hiring policies and the need for cost competitiveness. Companies are adopting contract hiring to add value with broad skill sets and experiences, but risk losing employees to competitors who may offer permanent positions. To mitigate this, companies should treat contract employees well, fairly, and with respect, and invest in their growth and development. The benefits for contract employees should be comparable to those of permanent staff, including flexible work schedules and a compensation plan. Organizations that balance contract and permanent employment can be more competitive and adaptable to market conditions.

site_title: Productivity gains, value creation winners at E50 Awards
summary: The Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards in Singapore recognized top 50 companies that leveraged productivity gains and value creation to maintain a competitive advantage despite a tough business environment. Excavation specialist Soon Li Heng Civil Engineering topped the list, while property developer Teambuild Land and homegrown pharmaceutical manufacturer Borden Company came in second and third respectively. Winners focused on productivity improvements and value creation to overcome labor crunch and rising business costs, with 28-year-old Ong Jun Quan of Soon Li Heng citing recycling waste material into reusable products as a key factor in their jump in ranking.
